title: no deal mars bar brexit jane moore
story: The operative word being “could”, of course. Same with Dairy Milk and Picnic bars too, apparently.Whatever, surely it’s a win-win situation  No more being bossed about by unelected Eurocrats and help tackle the obesity tooth rot crisis at the same time. But really, does anyone actually believe this Project Fear twaddle  No one has yet suggested that “no deal will see an end to Brussels sprouts”, but it can only be a matter of time.Meanwhile, we are still being peddled the prospect of medication piling up at the border, the entire City of London decamping to Paris, flights being grounded at the stroke of midnight on March , gridlocked motorwaysand “civil unrest”.Enough already. Like .million others, I voted for Brexit on the basis thatthe EU wouldn’t give us a mutually beneficial deal then we would simply leave without one.It’s now clear that, despite the clear mandate from . per cent of the British people that they want out, the painful preication of Mrs May’s “negotiations”has told the Brussels Eurocrats that our government is wavering on that mindset and, consequently, they feel they have us over an imported barrel.So it’s time to show them that they don’t — by openly preparing for no deal. After all, the notion that Merkel, Macron et al will bite off their own electorate’s noses to spite Britain’s volte face on EU membership is an absolute nonsense.In a letter to The Times yesterday, the chairman of pub chain JD Wetherspoon, Tim Martin, wrote: “The great urban myth, promoted by advocates of the deadly exchange rate mechanism, the euro and Remain, is that a ‘deal’ with the EU is a prerequisite of future prosperity.”The reality, he says, is that no deal would allow us to join successful countries such as Canada, Singapore, Israel and Australia in the free-trading world and “by slashing the EU’s , protectionist tarfs, shop prices will fall, with no loss to the Treasury, since tarf income is currently remitted to Brussels”.On top of that, we won’t have to pay the £billion orce bill, will regain control of our fishing waters, borders and laws and, ultimately, all have more money in our pockets. What’s not to love One expert from Economists for Free Trade did a few sums based on the boost in growthwe secure our financial and trading freedom against the impact of any no deal EU tarfs. The result  Calculated over ten years, the EU economy will lose by £billion while Britain’s will gain by more than £billion.Sweet as chocolate.A FAMILY in Caer-narfon, Gwynedd, is being allowed to continue covering their house in multi-coloured Christmas lights despite the complains of annoyed neighbours.Quite right too.I love it when people go all out with festive flamboyance.Just as long as they don’t live next to me.ASHLEY ROBERTS’ jive on Saturday’s Strictly  was indistinguishable from a professional.  And therein lies the problem.The original remit of this ratings juggernaut was that amateurs would be taught ballroom routines and morph before our eyes into graceful butterflies. Or, in John Sergeant and Ann Widdecombe’s case, common moths in freefall after a battering from a tea towel.But former Pussycat Doll Ashley is used to performing complicated dance routines in front of huge crowds and, therefore, oozed confidence and expertise from the get go.Little wonder since, according to her former dance teacher in the US, she was taught “all dferent styles of dance” from the age of eight to  and once had an introduction to ballroom training by an elite dance company at summer school.So yes, she’s undoubtedly the best, with former Steps trouper Faye Tozer not far behind. But the true Strictly stars are all the others who improve each week despite being way outside their comfort zone.FOLLOWING the shocking attack of a female PC being karate-kicked to the ground by a thug, the flippant commentary accompanying the footage is indeed sickening.But at least the film might help secure a prosecution and hopefully prove a turning point in how we take back control of our lawless streets.Because the real problem here is the fact that thugs clearly don’t fear the consequences of their actions.So may I humbly suggest that it’s high time the Home Office toughens up and shows, not tells, our hard-pressed police that they now have the power and support they need from on high to do their job effectively.CHECK out poo guru Gillian McKeith out on the town with her smiling -year-old daughter Skylar.Considering my daughters won’t be seen dead with meI wear anything more risqué than a baggy polo neck and tweed maxi skirt, she’s very fortunate indeed.THE £. Barbie Ultimate Kitchen has been named one of the top “must have” toys for Christmas, prompting criticism from those who think it panders to old-fashioned sexism.But one toy industry analyst counters: “She’s not just a housewe cooking for Ken. She’s watched The Great British Bake Off and she’s being innovative with her cooking.”Ever get the impression that the small kids being flogged this stuff are a darn sight brighter than the adults selling it BRITISH mother-of-four Becci Brennan has flown to the US to marry prisoner Travis Thompson, who has “hatred” tattooed on his forehead and is serving eight years for drug and gun offences.Of course she has.Let me guess – she’s going to be the one who changes him.MATTHEW CRAWFORD is st and blocking four beds in an NHS hospital because it can’t find a care home to take him.Probably because he also has convictions for attacking care home nurses and police and a racially aggravated assault. Nice.So far, his six-month stay at the Nottingham- shire-based hospital has cost the British taxpayer the princely sum of £,. Unsurprisingly, he’s on benefits, some of which he spends on “getting takeaways delivered” to his room.At what point does Matthew’s “human right” to gorge himself to such gargantuan proportions that he can barely move take second place to our right not to fund his gluttony and its resultant health issues ONE of supermarket Aldi’s advent calendars includes  bottles of wine for £.. And on the twelfth day of Christmas, my true love gave to me … a monster headache.SARAH FERGUSON has once again been waxing lyrical about how she and Prince Andrew are the “happiest orced couple” in the world.“We enjoy each other’s company, we allow each other to blossom,” she gushes.Are they – in the reverse spirit of Gwyneth and Chris – about to consciously recouple Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit bbc fact chuckers
story: We have no choice. In , we expect our national broadcaster to reflect all our opinions even-handedly.We don’t want the BBC to tell us that one side is right and the other wrong, or what we should believe, or which opinions are “true” and which are “”.But that is what the BBC has started to do, at least on the subject of Brexit.The BBC tried to be reasonably balanced during the referendum campaign, but it was so upset by the outcome that it has abandoned any attempt at impartiality and become grotesquely one-sided.The views of Remainers are not just over-represented, they are rarely challenged. And scare stories about Brexit which are either exaggerated or completely imaginary are presented as fact.I decided to compile a list of myths about Brexit — particularly scare stories about what will happen when we leave the Customs Union orwe leave Europe without a deal.Then I compared them with the facts. Although the pamphlet did not mention the BBC, most of the myths were things we hear daily on its programmes.The BBC rose to the bait and invited me into the Today programme on Radio  yesterday to be grilled by John Humphrys, its star interviewer. It was a fair enough interview. He challenged my arguments but I was able to refute his claims point by point.However, they then brought on a chap called Chris Morris, described as the BBC “reality checker”, who was invited to rebut my document. But all he did was oppose my facts with the opinions of people with whom he agreed.He systematically argued the Remain case and defended their Project Fear scare stories. The one thing he did not do was bring in any new facts. My central claim was thatwe leave the EU Customs Union but have a free trade agreement with the European Union, our businesses have little to fear.The main dference will be that traders will have to send in a customs declaration detailing the goods they are buying from or selling to Europe.That is a nuisance which we should try to simply as much as possible.But allegations that “this will be hugely costly, cause y delays, disrupt supply chains and undermine economic growth” are imaginary or exaggerated.“Fact checker” Morris said the majority of trade experts and freight companies to whom he had spoken robustly disagreed with me. This is an opinion, not a fact.Surely,trading in a free trade area — like that which exists between Switzerland and the EU or between Canada and the US — is so intolerable, the people there would be calling for a customs union.But they aren’t. I prefer their practical experience to the speculation of Mr Morris’s contacts.I also quoted a report by the CLECAT organisation, which covers , companies handling  per cent of the freight and customs in Europe, who said: “All the ingredients to ensure a smooth exit process of the UK from the EU, and which allow almost frictionless trade after the exit, are already available.”Why should a BBC fact checker’s unnamed contacts count for more than their considered view He then claimed there are no checks at the border at present. I go across to my house in France frequently and see the checks — for drugs, illegal immigrants, alcohol, cigarettes.And companies have to report all their cross-border trade separately on their VAT s and provide statistical s to Brussels.Then Mr Morris claimed there would be more checks by our customs officers at Dover, resulting in delays and disruption. That is nonsense.The Head of Customs and Revenue has said it only stops and searches lorries at present where it has intelligence information about drugs, illegal immigrants, and goods such as tobacco and alcohol, upon which excise duty is paid.It does not expect any of these risks to become more frequent. So it will not need to search any more vehicles.As I was still in the studio, I was able to rebut his pathetic attempts to rebut my facts. Normally he gets a clear run.But what is intolerable is that he almost never tries to rebut arguments by those trying to overturn the referendum result.I asked him afterwards to name a single Remainer whose case he had attempted to dissect. When he replied that there were “lots”, I said it should be easy to name one and, after repeated challenges, he named Jeremy Corbyn.The idea that Mr Corbyn — a man who has voted more often against European membership than any other MP and went on holiday during the referendum — is a Remainer could only be taken for reality by a BBC reality checker.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dup is not bluffing backstop
story: They want the Irish “backstop”, which weakens the Britain Northern Ireland union, binned. Or they’ll collapse the Tory Government their votes prop up.To the DUP the sanctity of the union is everything — far more fundamental even than keeping Corbyn, a notorious supporter of the IRA, and a united Ireland, out of Downing Street. Mrs May’s deal is an immediate threat.Corbyn can be fought later,he ever takes power. The Sun doesn’t see the DUP coming round. The PM must fix the backstop.No, the EU won’t play ball. But the deal is in disarray anyhow, here and in Brussels. Spain, France and Germany want it rewritten to punish us further. Others want more fishing rights. Our MPs won’t back it as it is, let alone an even harder version.But, that aside, Mrs May cannot govern at all without the DUP. And she must not try just to tough this out.She and Michel Barnier need solutions.WILL the Tories ever put the public health busybodies back in their box The fizzy drinks tax was just the start. As The Sun always predicted, they’re now after everything  . . . yoghurts, cereals, takeaways, you name it.They claim customers want the food industry to cut sugar — and that the Government must use “fiscal levers”needed to enforce it. That’s a weasel phrase meaning “new taxes consumers will end up paying”.Yes, obesity is a problem. But the reality of this demented war on the calories and sugar in our food supply — in place of educating Brits about diet and exercise — is blander grub or smaller portions . . . inevitably for the same price.Shoppers will then rightly turn on these same un-Conservative politicians and nanny-state meddlers who foolishly thought we were all onboard.WITH every utterance, Justice Secretary David Gauke makes his Government’s shambolic stance over the John Worboys parole scandal worse.There is no case for  members remaining anonymous. And to dismiss their role as “administrative” is crass.We still don’t know who decided to free the rapist, nor who rightly overturned that judgement. But we should.Parole  often make rulings with le-or-death implications for the ­public. They must be as accountable and identiable as any judge.Mr Gauke is normally one of the Government’s most unflappable performers. But, after first cravenly bottling out of a judicial review over Warboys’ parole, he is now championing secrecy.When in a hole, Mr Gauke, stop digging.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: universal credit five week wait could be slashed amber rudd hints
story: When asked about whether she would cut the wait for new claimants, the DWP boss said she was looking at what we can do to get cash into peoples hands earlier.It comes after she promised to fix problems with the flagship benefits system and accepted there were areas in which it wasnt working.She told the BBC today that the biggest problem is getting cash into peoples hands as soon as they need it.Advance payments are available for Brits who cant wait five weeks for money, but that has to be paid back immediately out of their first UC sum.Ms Rudd said her department would make it clear to people they can get that upfront as soon as they apply and then pay it back over  months.On a damning report by a UN representative earlier this week, she promised to look at the concerns with women and single mums in particular.But she blasted the findings as being too political and implying the system was there to negatively impact Brits.The aim is to help people when they need it, and help them into work, she told Radio s Today programme.Our motives are to be efficient and compassionate.Ministers have already announced they will give an extra two weeks of several benefits to people on Universal Credit in future - but this wont come in until .At the moment people moving onto the new system get an extra two weeks of just housing benefit to help them cope with the switch.Ms Rudd insisted: The main message I want to give is that Universal Credit is a force for good and we will see how we can fix it.The new benefits system has been beset with issues since it first began being rolled out in .One chippy owner said yesterday the new system was pushing Brits AWAY from work as people couldnt figure out whether they would be better off or not.And earlier this week one desperate mum told how she was forced into sex work to get money for food after waiting for her first payment.One in six Brits still arent getting their first sum on time, the latest Universal Credit stats showed.MANY MPs can’t imagine being truly broke.We don’t mean a bit skint, having to max out the credit card or raid the savings account. We mean having literally no money and going hungry.So it is good to see Amber Rudd, in her first week as Work and Pensions Secretary, consider slashing the five-week wait many claimants endure before their Universal Credit comes through.We support the new benefits system. It is simpler and incentivises work.But that hold-up is unfair and causes real hardship. Sort it, Amber.

title: louis theroux adoption
story: Im excited to meet my birth mum, says Isaiah. Ive been waiting for  years. Some birthdays Id cry because she wasnt there.Isaiah is one of an estimated , children who are given up for adoption every year in the US.Increasingly, open adoption is becoming more popular: a business worth billions of dollars where those looking to adopt pay up to £, for a newborn via agencies that match kids to prospective parents.In the final episode of his new series Altered States, Louis Theroux travels to Southern Calornia to find out more about the practice - discovering that while it helps create new, loving families it is also at risk of exploitation - as birth mothers can change their minds but adopters wont be refunded.According to Irene Riley - who runs the adoption agency Rainbow’s End Adoption Services in LA -many women give up their kids due to problems with drink and drugs or running into financial dficulty.Isaiahs mum Trina struggled with a crystal meth addiction for many years.Then when she was heavily pregnant with her son, her partner beat her up and left her for dead.I prayed to God and saidyou save me and the baby I promise Ill do whats right for him, she says.Now clean and living a good le, Trina is incredibly grateful to Isaiahs adoptive mum Joanne for including her in his sons le.“I told you when you was in my tummy I loved you but I was giving you the chance to have a better le, with good people. I always wanted you to be OK,” she tells Isaiah.Louis says this positive reunion seems a tribute to open adoption.However, theres not always a happy ending with open adoption, as Louis discovers when he meets Patricia, a pregnant former nurse who is living hand to mouth in motels after falling on hard times.Like Trina, she has also struggled with drug addiction and had numerous run-ins with the law -something Louis expresses concern over.Patricia already has three kids of her own, but says now she simply cant afford to have a fourth. I never saw myself in this position, she says. But my little girl will be able to have a much better le this way.She is matched with a couple, Ari and Amy, who already have three boys but desperately want a girl to complete their brood.As part of the process, Ari and Amy agree to pay Patricia £,a month living expenses.However, she starts to go AWOL, not updating the couple or Irene on her progress and only briefly turning up whenever she needs to collect money - cash Louis worries is going on drugs.Under Calornia law, a woman has  days to change her mind about putting her baby up for adoption.This loophole means the practice of open adoption comes with risk: parents dont get a refund for any money theyve already put in, meaning they can lose thousands of pounds, and there is a lack of regulation.There have been a number of scams in the US. In  a Kansas woman, Roxanne Jones, conned ten couples out of money by ly claiming she was pregnant.In April this year a Louisiana woman, Betty Jo Krenz was jailed after running an agency that produced fake adoption papers.And in November  Shareen Gurnsey, from Alabama, was charged with theft by deception after taking money from one couple while promising her unborn child to three others, matching with them through separate adoption agencies.And it appears Ari and Amy have fallen victim to a scam by Patricia, who becomes increasingly elusive as her due date looms.Eventually, Irene makes contact with her, finding out that Patricia gave birth to her baby in a motel by herself and now wants to keep the child, leaving Ari and Amy, who have already decorated a nursery, devastated.Amy tells Louis that Irene had received a message from Patricia telling them to leave me alone so I can enjoy my new baby you guys are ruining this for me.For those like Isaiah, theres happy endings.However, Louis concludes by saying there is an inbuilt tension in open adoption between the needs of the often vulnerable birth mum and the ever hopeful adopters.It is a process open to abuse and however it happens, pain is intrinsic to it.Louis Theroux Altered States: Take My Baby airs on BBC Two at pm on Sunday  NovemberOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: universal credit man live on pasta gravy mistake
story: Alun Krem-Szczesniak had hundreds of pounds cut from his payments because they wrongly believed he was getting carers allowance.The -year-old, from Pontardawe in Wales, said his experience with the new welfare system has been horrible and he was getting into debt because of errors the DWP made.Alun, who stopped working after contracting glandular fever, is entitled to £ a month, but for two months on the trot a mistake meant he only got half of that - £.The DWP told him it was because he was getting a carers allowance which knocked it down, but he hasnt been claiming that since his father died more than a year ago.He told Wales Online: It has been so humiliating - I have no pride left now. I shouldnt have to be begging people for money or for food.He went on: Friends and family have had to give me money - but I will still have to give them their money back.If it wasnt for them, I would be getting into more and more debt.But there are people that dont have friends or family they can turn to.I was going to my sisters house because I knew that I would have a cooked meal then.I dont think I would be hereit wasnt for the help I have had - I think I would have killed myself, or I would definitely have thought about it.There were times that I felt there was no way out. It has been horrible.Eventually Alun was paid the money he was owed, only for the same mistake to happen again the next month.He claims his landlord has been understanding about his late rent payments, but  bill companies are already chasing him for money.He already owes £ for his water, gas and electricity bills, and cant afford to start thinking about Christmas or even run his car.I have had to prioritise and a roof over my head is my first priority - I cant pay for my utilities at the moment so I dont have any choice but to ignore it, he said.I cant budget for anything - I cant buy any Christmas presents at the moment, it is a case of day to day living.A spokesman for the DWP said: “We have paid Mr Krem-Szczesniak the benefits due to him and we are contacting him to discuss his claim as a matter of urgency.We apologise for any inconvenience caused.”Universal Credit, which replaces six benefits with one, is being rolled out across the country - and will be in every area by the end of the year for new claimants.But its been beset with problems and Brits say its forcing them into debt and they never have any idea how much they will be getting.One single mum said she was forced to take £ for sex work just to make ends meet while she waited for her benefits to come through.The new DWP boss Amber Rudd has vowed to fix problems with the benefit system - and has even hinted she could slash the five week wait for payments.

title: universal credit keep benefits two weeks
story: And Brits who are already on the system shouldnt all have to make a fresh application or face getting their payments cut altogether, influential MPs on the Work and Pensions committee said.Ministers are considering how best to move millions of Brits from the old benefits system to the new one.They will vote within weeks on their rules on how best to do this - but some are calling for that vote to be delayed so theres enough time to fix vital issues.They said in a fresh report that there must be an additional two week payment for those on Universal Credit to help ease the pain. And they said there should be NO five-week wait for those who transfer over, and anyone who the DWP already have the information for should not have to apply again.At the moment Brits are entitled to two weeks of extra help with their housing payments, making the wait for their next sum effectively three weeks.Chancellor Philip Hammond revealed in the Budget that this will be extended to people on JSA and ESA - but not until .That still means anyone on tax credits wont get the extra two weeks of help.Committee chair Frank Field said of the Universal Credit changes: The Committee’s main proposals seek to ensure that the risk of moving claimants from the old system of benefits onto Universal Credit lies with the Government and not on the shoulders of poorer people.The Government is thankfully making and then remaking its policy on how best to transfer existing claimants onto Universal Credit.It would be a pitythe Government undermined this new way of thinking by not giving Parliament and SSAC enough time to comment on its latest changes before it pushes Parliament into a vote.The new system, which replaces six benefits with one, is being rolled out across the country - title: city worker turns horse box cabin van travel world cosy
story: The converted horse box boasts beautul upholstery, stunning Douglas fir woodwork and a panoramic window next to a cosy dinner table.Incredibly the stunning mobile home also has all mod cons - with an indoor cinema, full-size cooker, shower, spacious fridge and a fully-upholstered sofa.The spacious xft Mercedes -D cost just £, to buy and convert- half the price of a parking space in Londons posh Barbican Estate.It was lovingly crafted by Guy Williams, , who hit the road after becoming disaffected with a -year career in surveying before he moved into hotel management.After a pay-out from his last job he bought and converted the van in just a year and is now travelling across Europe with his -month-old Cockapoo puppy Ethel.Mr Williams, who is currently in Portugal, said: Basically I was sick of it.I used to be a charted surveyor in Bristol and I quit that because I didnt want to be in a   everyday until I was .I looked around me and all the people there were rotting behind their desks.I left and I started living in my other van and rented out my flat in Bristol and I was earning more money doing that than I was surveying.He added: After doing that for a while I wanted to do something a bit bigger and I ended up buying this horse box from Holland and driving it back.I kitted it out with the intention of living in it, I did it over a year but I reckon I couldve done it in just two months.We were going for a log-cabin style and we were inspired by the Alps - it is basically a log cabin in a van.It is more kitted out than a lot of flats, it has everything I need.This is a house on wheels and it cost just £, and you can park up anywhere.You cant even put a deposit down for that.After finishing building the van earlier this year Mr Williams set off in early September - with plans afoot to head to Morocco and finish up by celebrating his birthday in the Alps.When his trip is over the intrepid explorer plans to refurbish vans into homes after his unusual home sparked interest in the UK.Several conversions have been lined up and he will take them on after ing in Spring.He said: Im not doing the conversions to make loads of money Im doing them because I enjoy it.Back in the day people would call you a crustyyou live in the back of a van and people would look down their noses at you, but now it is cool to live in a van.It is not mainstream, but it is not to rebel - it is free living and you are off grid.All you need is your fuel and cost of the food, there is no worries of paying bills or a red letter.Van le is so cheap and you have the bonus of being able to go anywhere you want to go and you have everything you need in a box.

title: britain worst female paedo disguise identity
story: Vanessa George earned the grisly title in  after she was caged for taking  pictures of herself harming babies and toddlers at a nursery she worked at.George is now eligible for parole and a hearing is expected early next year - meaning she could be back on the streets next month, Plymouth Herald reports.The newspaper says she has changed her name while in prison - reverting to her maiden name of Vanessa Sylvia Marks.She is planning to follow in the footsteps of Tracy Lyons - one of the four members of the paedophile ring led by Georges online lover Colin Blanchard.Lyons, who was jailed in  for sending sickening child abuse pictures to Blanchard, changed her name after she released just nine months later.Georges change comes after she orced husband Andrew, who has said he would jump for joyshe killed herself.The mum-of-two described herself to Blanchard as a paedo whore mum in vile exchanges between the two.She worked at Little Teds nursery in Efford, Plymouth, where she sexually assaulted a number of children in her care and sent indecent images to her lover.George admitted to a total of seven sexual assaults of young children and six counts of distributing and making indecent pictures of children.She was sentenced to seven years Blanchards other online lover, ex-prostitute Angela Allen.Tracy Dawber, who was in a year-long relationship with the paedo ringleader, was caged for four years for abusing a two-year-old boy and letting Blanchard film it.Blanchard - described as the hub of the paedophile wheel at his sentencing - was given a minimum term of nine years in .

title: jacob rees mogg says he wont stand to replace theresa may as feuding tory brexiteers turn on each other after coup flop
story: The top Brexiteer joked thathe put his hat in the ring it would be thrown back at him like Bond villain Oddjob.And he suggested that Boris would make a better PM because he makes politics interesting and has the qualities of leadership.Mr Rees-Moggs comments came as his allies in the European Research Group turned on each other in the wake of the failed coup against the PM.Writing in the Spectator, Mr Rees-Mogg defended his decision to call for a vote of no confidence in Mrs May.He admitted: It was naive of me to expect the Prime Minister to change her policy. It is not how it works - the wrong policy means the wrong person.But he added: If there were a leadership election, which I hope there will be, I would not throw my hat into the ring as I fear it would be thrown back ‘Oddjob’ style.The ERG chair hinted he would end up supporting Boris, saying that Tory activists are enthusiastic about the prospect of the ex-Foreign Secretary taking power.Mr Rees-Mogg wrote: He certainly makes politics interesting and has the qualities of leadership.A week ago today, the leading Brexiteer announced he had sent a letter to backbench chief Sir Graham Brady calling for Mrs May to go.But the revelation failed to spark the expected cascade of letters which would have forced a vote of confidence in the PM.Last night, ERG member Nadine Dorries blasted her Brexiteer allies who failed to join the revolt against Mrs May.In a furious WhatsApp message leaked to the Guido Fawkes website, she wrote: There are a handful of you who have badly let the ERG down as a group, opening us up to ridicule and abuse in the media and online.I am referring to those MPs who have not put their letters in.It is being said that you have let the side down and are not the type of people anyone would want to go into battle with.The Brexiteer rebels are now pinning their hopes on a fresh push for a leadership challenge next month, after the PMs deal is voted on by MPs.BORIS Johnson earned almost £ a minute giving a speech to a finance firm in New York, it emerged last night.The former Foreign Secretary raked in a staggering £, for the two hour talk which comes on top of his £, a month salary for a Dailycolumn and his £, a year MP’s salary.He was addressing the US Golden Tree Asset Management firm in the Big Apple earlier this month.Mr Johnson also took in a £, donation for his office and staffing costs.And he pocketed a further £, in royalties from his books.The figures came from the MP’s official register of interests.

title: punter suing betfred refusing payout
story: Andrew Green, , splashed out while celebrating after becoming a millionaire playing a game on Betfreds website.But five days later the bookie told him he would not be receiving the cash because there had been a software mal.The dad-of-two turned down a £, settlement, which required a nondisclosure agreement, and is now fighting his case in the High Court.He told BBC News: They [Betfred] are quick to take peoples money but when it comes to paying out they offered money as a gagging agreement.How many are there out there who have signed similar agreements Andrew said: Ive been bullied. Im just a fish in a big sea and they are a great big shark but Im not going to be forced away just because they are worth billions and Im not.Eventhere was a glitch I did nothing wrong. I played that game and pressed a button.Back in January Andrew, of Washingborough, Lincolnshire, started playing Frankie Dettoris Magic Seven with a £ stake.He lost almost all of his money to the online game but managed to work his way up from £ to £,.But one final play won him the £.million jackpot, he claims.Jubilant Andrew spent £, as he toasted his new-found fortune down the pub.But Betfred later voided the win, claiming there was a glitch in the new game release.Peter Coyle, Andrews solicitor, claims the company has refused repeated requests to provide evidence of the computer problem.A preliminary High Court hearing was told this week the company did not have the game data and so could not force the game developer to hand it over.A spokesman for Betfred said: Betfred loves to pay out all our jackpot winners, both big and small.Unfortunately, and as Mr Green is aware, a new game release suffered a software mal in January this year and no legitimate jackpot win occurred.Given that Mr Green is currently exploring his legal options, it would be inappropriate for us to comment further.In , Betfred was forced to remove a slot game from their site after a punter was ly told he won £,.Jamie Gardiner, from Kirkby, Liverpool, was playing the “Land of Gold” game when he got three clovers.A pop up then appeared saying “Win: £,.”.The -year-old was over the moon but soon become concerned when the cash was not credited to his online Betfred account. Mr Gardiner said hed won money in the same way before before, but Betfred insisted it wasnt legitimate.   At the time, he said: I play all the time and I know when it comes up there it is meant to go straight into your balance.“I got two mushrooms and three clovers and whenever you get three clovers you are credited with the jackpot.”

title: stalker partner love contract marry
story: Lina Tantash, , drove college tutor Jarlath Rice, , to the brink of suicide bombarding him with emails and calls and harassing his colleagues.The pair met while working in Dublin in  and had a fling which lasted less than a month.When Mr Rice broke off the sexual relationship with the increasingly-demanding Tantash, she ordered him to sign a -caluse “love contract” while claiming he owed her £,.The bizarre agreement stipulated he should stop denying they were in a relationship despite the Irishman telling her to stop contacting him.It also stated he should live with her three days a week, speak to her on the phone for at least  minutes every evening and be nice to her.She even hired a private detective to hunt him down, look into his private le and obtain his contact details.Jordanian-born Tantash was sentenced to four years in prison today after she was convicted of two counts of stalking.As she was sentenced her mother broke down in court and begged the judge for mercy for her daughter.Lewes Crown Court heard the extraordinary saga began in  when the “highly intelligent” university-educated project manager met Mr Rice, an Irish filmmaker, when they were both working in Dublin in .After Tantash began harassing him, Mr Rice fled to Brighton, East Sussex, where he started work as a college tutor.But the stalker, then a “highly-respected” project manager at prestigious Trinity College Dublin, followed him taking up a new role in London.Her campaign of harassment escalated after she suspected Mr Rice, who was working as a tutor at DV College in Brighton, had started a relationship with work colleague, Sarah Bolland.She began bombarding Miss Bolland with abusive phone calls and emails at the college demanding she stop seeing Mr Rice.Miss Bolland, who was not romantically involved with Mr Rice, was devastated by the abusive calls.On one occasion Tantash called her and said: “Stay away from him, whore! Stay away from Jarlath, bitch. I’m going to f******g kill you.”On another she said “You don’t see him, you don’t date him and don’t f**k him. I’ll kill myself. Would you rather have my blood on your hands ”And in another Tantash was recorded saying: “You look like a horse and you’re an ugly f******g bitch.”In an email to her she told Miss Bolland she had “disgusting frizzy hair, skin like curdled yoghurt and buck teeth” and that she hoped she had a “heartbroken, horrid end”.Tantash also sent abusive emails from several anonymous accounts to friends, family and work colleagues demanding Mr Rice’s mobile number, his home address and other details.She bombarded one colleague with  phone calls in one evening asking that he hand over Mr Rice’s mobile phone number and even offered him £, for the information.On the evening of an open night at DV College Tantash ordered around £ of takeaway pizzas and had them delivered to the college.She was eventually arrested and charged with one count of stalking Mr Rice between July  - February  and one count of stalking Miss Bolland. She was convicted after a trial at Brighton Magistrates Court.In a victim impact statement Mr Rice said the campaign of stalking left him on the brink of suicide and had been in “despair”.He said: “For over  years I’ve had to live with verbal, mental and physical abuse.“The aggressive and abusive dismantling of my le has left me vulnerable, frightened and exhausted.”Mr Rice said he had been “pushed deep into depression” adding: “At my worst I have gone through periods of despair with suicide ideation.”In her defence, Tantash said she came from a stable, upper middle class family but was suffering from a mental condition.She claimed to have paid Mr Rice’s sizeable debts and supported his career infor a romantic commitment.Miss Bolland said: “It’s a strange and terrible experience when someone psychologically harasses you like this.“It’s an awful feeling. It’s astonishing how much it can impact your le, your mood, your thoughts.”Teresa Mulrooney, defending, said: “Miss Tantash deeply regrets her behaviour and has come to understand the impact it has had.”Sentencing her, Recorder Stephen Lennard, said: “You were never prepared to accept it was over and thereafter carried out a sustained and vicious campaign of stalking and harassment that lasted  years.“In my opinion you are vicious, devious and manipulative woman. You should be thoroughly ashamed of what you have done to Mr Rice and Miss Bolland.”He also handed her a restraining order.

title: mum converts islam marry gambian toyboy
story: Heidi Hepworth, , wears a hijab and prays to Allah every day as she prepares for her big day.She is planning a wedding in a mosque in The Gambia, where most of the population is Muslim and which Heidi says is “a happier and more caring place than Britain”.Insisting her relationship with Mamadou Salieu Jallow, , is the real thing, she said: “No-one imagined this would last but we love each other and are making plans to marry. I’ve never been happier.”Heidi split with her car mechanic husband of  years last year when she hooked up with her lover on Facebook.Friends reckoned it would hit the rocks within weeks.At the time, husband Andy, , from Hetton-le-Hole, Tyne and Wear, said: “It’s a mid-le crisis. She’s been brainwashed.But Heidi, who had never been in a plane in her le, has now been to West Africa four times to see her taxi driver boyfriend.She plans to move there after they marry next year once her orce is finalised.Heidi, who has six children with Andy and three from a previous marriage, said she popped the question.“I think it’s fine to take the initiative,” she said.“I have wasted enough time in my le in an unhappy marriage.”Ex-husband Andy had also criticised Heidi for leaving her kids.He said: A caring mum wouldn’t go off ­gallivanting around Africa with her new boyfriend.”But speaking exclusively to The Sun last year, she defended her actions, saying: “I don’t have a single regret. I’m not a terrible parent.“It was really hard for me to leave my kids, but they couldn’t come with me so I had no choice.“I was shocked at the anger that was directed at me for supposedly abandoning my children. That just didn’t happen.”Heidi, from West Boldon, South Tyneside, has two sons and a daughter aged  to  from a previous relationship. She and Andy have three daughters aged seven, ten and  and three sons aged ,  and .When she left, the three youngest moved in with her eldest daughter.Heidi added: She moved into my home while I was away so that they were disrupted as little as possible.“I went online every night and we video-chatted. They seemed happy and I know my kids well.They also chatted to Salieu and have become very fond of him through talking online over the past few months.“If people think I went over to The Gambia and didn’t give them a second thought, they are so wrong.“But having said that, I make no apologies for following my heart. I’ve been unhappy for a long time and I think I have found someone to spend the rest of my le with.“We are in love and nothing will stop me from marrying him. If other people don’t like that they will just have to lump it.”Heidis African romance made her the talk of town in Hetton-le-Hole in Sunderland.Andy blames the Facebook love affair for the couples split, but Heidi insisted their loveless marriage was over long before she received the friend request from Salieu.Heidi said: “Andy and I didn’t even share a bedroom, never mind a bed, for the last two years of our marriage.We were both unhappy and on some days the most conversation I would get from him would be when he’d say, ‘Put the kettle on’.“At the end of last year I picked up his phone to look up a number my daughter wanted and saw messages from two women. It was a big shock.“We drted even further apart and I was so unhappy. I started volunteering at the children’s school, just so I had some contact with other people and could feel better about myself.Heidi appeared on Loose Women in February to defend her relationship with the African business owner.Viewers took to Twitter to accuse her of being deluded.One said: Can we have an update of this woman in a few months time when shes been fleeced of all her money. Im sorry shes deluded.Heidi however says Salieu is not dating her for financial gain. “He doesnt want nothing. He has three businesses. He has his own passport, his own visa - why would he ask me for a visahes got one, she said.“He comes regularly to England to visit his brothers son. His brother had a we here whos tragically died. And they come regularly.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: handyman two live pipe bombs london
story: John Brooks, , found the in devices with fuses poking out in a kitchen cupboard.He told friends he handled them thinking they were fireworks.But after sleeping on it and learning the former tenant was an ex-soldier he urged bosses to call the police.John shared a snap of the bombs wrapped in tape online. Cops believe they were viable.The building in Harlesden, North West London, contains mostly housing association flats.A mate said: “He was just tidying up, cleaning and giving the place a lick of paint for the next tenant.“At first he thought they were bangers, so thought nothing much of it.”Management later told him who had been living there.The pal added: “Once he realised who had built them, he felt very uneasy and realised thatthey had gone off he’d have been killed.“Not only that, but these bedsits are tiny — so the places nearby would have gone too.”A neighbour said: “There is all sorts of trouble around here. This is unusual though.”A man of  is being quizzed by police. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: abusive boyfriend girlfriend too strong
story: Paul Measor, , subjected former partner Lauren Smith, , to daily abuse and even trained their one-year-old son to call her a s**g and a s**t.She recorded his vile outbursts - which included him spitting in her face - which were played to the court.He was convicted of common assault and jailed for five months - but he was cleared of the offence of using controlling and coercive behaviour.District Judge Helen Cousins said she had to decide whether his behaviour had a serious effect on the victim.She said the behaviour was disgraceful but didnt have a big enough impact on Lauren to find him guilty.Schools learning manager Lauren hit back: It has had a serious effect.Im attending meetings with a domestic violence support group, my confidence has been badly knocked and I struggle to trust people.He controlled my le for four years and the effect of that didnt go away the minute he was taken away by the police. It still hasnt, its going to take time.She said that his forthcoming appeal will drag up the same issues.Lauren added: It doesnt matter whether a woman is considered strong and capable or not,they are subjected to that kind of behaviour it surely goes without saying that its had a serious effect on them.Katie Ghose, Chief Executive of Women’s Aid, said: “No judge should base their judgement of a domestic abuse-related case on whether the victim matches their stereotype of what a victim should look or act like.Coercive and controlling behaviour is at the heart of domestic abuse and has a long-lasting and devastating impact on the survivor.Danielle Chadwick, of Hartlepool-based anti-domestic violence group Harbour, added: “We want victims to feel able to come forwardthey are experiencing this kind of abuse.During the trial Lauren said that Measor, who ran his own maintenance company, tracked her movements whenever she went out using an app.She had to send him Snapchats to prove she was at certain places and knew her phone and social media passwords.In a recording played to court the couples young son can be heard being told to tell her to f*** off.Judge Cousins said: I have to be satisfied the behaviour was controlling, coercive, and it had a serious effect on the victim.Theres no doubt the victim is a strong and capable woman, whose evidence was truthful.She has since successfully removed herself from the harmful situation.

title: smoking construction workers gas tanks
story: A passer-by snapped the hapless duo puffing away in a cordoned-off part of the city centre road which was open to traffic.The pair were working on water main and sewer connections in Inverness.Michael Freeman, who owns the nearby Panasonic Store, said: “I find it completely unacceptable. It’s just common sense that the two things don’t go together.”The work is being carried out by local firm William Gray Construction as part of refurbishment of the old Citizens Advice building.A spokesman for the company confirmed an inquiry was underway.He said the men were subcontractors who broke strict no smoking rules but there was was “no increased level of danger”.He added: “All employees sign to acknowledge our site rules.The safety of the workers, the public and businesses is a priority, and we are looking in to how this incident occurred.”Highland Council said construction safety is not its responsibility.We told earlier how vaping could be as bad for as smoking cigarettes, according to one study.Greek researchers found that flavourings in e-cigarettes harm the lungs by causing inflammation.It comes after smokers were told they could be banned from lighting up in their council homes and given vaping kits.

title: theresa may woolly brexit deal
story: But it is still just a woolly and even contradictory wishlist that barely binds Brussels to anything.The cost of these vague promises  Some  thousand million pounds.This “political declaration” about the future is predicated on Brussels negotiating a trade deal in good faith, a ­quality they have never shown since the referendum result they are even now desperate to overthrow.Why would their puerile desire to “punish” Britain abate once we nominally leave next March Especially when under the terms now agreed they can trap us in the Customs Union for ever The PM claims the EU wouldn’t want us there, benefiting from it for free, having ended free movement. But that’s a price Brussels will surely pay to cripple us as a trading rival on their doorstep.That said, the deal is NOT all bad.Downing Street rightly trumpets that it ends free movement and our massive membership subscription, protects jobs and secures our fishing rights .And Mrs May, to her considerable credit, pushed the EU into an extraordinary U-turn over a high-tech solution to police the Irish border. Remember how glibly they once sneered at that idea Trouble is, who trusts them not to change heart againthe appalling “Irish backstop” alternative suits them The trade deal may take years. Anyone could veto it: Spain over Gibraltar. Or the Belgian Walloons who almost wrecked the EU Canada deal. We would be stuck.And while Mrs May’s deal enshrines our right to an independent trade policy, it also says any new partnership with the EU must “build on” a single customs territory.That’s why Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab quit — it ­scuppers any deals where.The one straw we clutch is that Jeremy Corbyn isn’t negotiating.None of his scripted lines, nor his brow furrowed in supposed concentration, can hide that the entire debate sails over his head.Don’t imagine the chaos couldn’t be worse.WE heartily approve of primary kids being tasked with damming streams, canoeing and playing conkers.Sure, it’s a bit Swallows And Amazons. And a big ask in Moss Side or Tower Hamlets. But children do spend far too much time gawping at screens.Education Secretary Damian Hinds wants that to change. All power to him.FOR years The Sun has condemned the web giants for facilitating terrorism.Now MPs have concluded the same: Google and Facebook are a “safe haven” for online extremists who radicalise and mould killers.If they will not purge their sites, vast fines must force them.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mum of fives horror at maggot infested council home where giant rats roam free
story: Michele Smith, , was even able to film one of the giant rodents roaming free in the Birmingham home.Im at rock-bottom, explained Michele.Were not living next to rats, were living with them.Ive trodden on a headless rat on the kitchen floor with my bare feet, they are just everywhere. Theres umpteen of them, dozens easily.My kitchen, at the moment, is totally off limits.Me and the kids have been eating on my bed in my bedroom. Its no way to bring up your children.We should all be eating at the table like normal families do. Were just too scared to go downstairs its that bad. Just the other day I was about to make some toast for the kids and a rat was sitting on the toaster looking straight at me.Now, Ive put how many pieces of bread in that toaster It makes you feel sick. Were just mortied. The b******s are everywhere. Theyre bigger than squirrels.Michele, who lives in the ground-floor flat with three of her children aged four,  and , has been suffering from panic attacks and, just a fortnight ago, had to have her heart re-started by doctors.Im on sleeping tablets because I cant sleep, she explained. Im taking anti-depressants and I suffer from panic attacks a lot.I had to have an adrenaline jab to restart my heart two weeks ago. I had heart failure. My heart was racing  beats-per-minute instead of .The place, my home, is falling apart. I havent had a bath since the rd of August because theres a massive hole in the bath. Thats three months we havent been able to bath or shower.Me and the kids have been going to my mates house half-hour away in Quinton every few days.Ive been packing wash bags, pyjamas and well all go there of a school night to have a bath and a wash. We cant live like this.The rats absolutely stink. Weve had the rat man out countless times putting bait and poison down and hes adamant theres no holes around the perimeter for them to come in from but they just keep appearing and, the worst thing is, theyre not even scared of you and just look straight at you.Of a night you can hear them scurrying around the house, squealing. Ive shut up and put up for too long. Its not a living. Ive usually let bygones be bygones but not now.My babys room is full of damp, the walls are growing mushrooms and weve had maggots falling through the air vents. The bathroom is constantly full of flies.Single mum Michelle is now contemplating declaring her and her young children homeless.Im going to go to the homeless housing shelter, she said.What do I doI want to bath the kids tonight  Ive got no family and I cant keep going to my friends house.Do I go to a hotel, pay for it and claim it back  I just dont know what to do. Weve got to get out of here. I cant go on and I need help.A Birmingham City Council spokesperson said: “Housing officers visited the tenant on Tuesday following a report of rats at the property, with environmental health officers visiting today.We will be carrying out works to seal entry points to the property’s drains as well as fitting a gully grid.”The council said that according to their records rats at the property were first reported to them in December , with a second report in March this year.

title: school pupil adult asylum seeker faces deportation
story: The pupil - alleged to be an asylum seeker from the Middle East - now faces being deported after an official report assessed him as being over  years of age.An investigation was launched when a pupil posted a picture of their new classmate in unorm in a classroom on Snapchat with a message saying: “How’s there a -year-old man in our maths class ”Parents were shocked, and some even removed their children from the school as classmates shared old pictures of him on Facebook, showing him with a full beard, a hairy chest and swigging a beer.Sources confirmed that the ft in tall pupil who spoke poor English was assessed as being aged over  in an investigation ordered by the Home Office.He has since been removed from the school earlier this month.While the Home Office has refused to reveal the newly-assessed age of the man - or any details of his background due to data protection issues - it is now understood that he is being treated as an adult asylum seeker.He could now face being thrown out of the UKhis claim for asylum is denied.A further probe into how he managed to pass as a student is being carried out.He welcomed news that the pupil had been identied as a male, saying: “All I wanted in the first place was for him to be removed and he has been.“My thoughts are that I’m ashamed both for the school and the Government for allowing this to happen. They have both failed to protect our children.Mr Newby kept his daughters away from the school after finding out about the pupil and only let themwhen he was certain the man was not going back.Sandy Martin, the Labour MP for Ipswich, said the Home Office “need to get their act together” to ensure adults cannot pose as children in the classroom.He said: “The Home Office needs to make sure that they are not sending people who are overage to school.“They have the means to do this and they need to do it. It doesn’t help the young people involved any more than it helps the schools.“I think the fact that it has had such a high profile in the news has made sure that the Home Office will do their job a bit better in the future, although the history of the Home Office doing its job a bit better isn’t very encouraging.”The stepfather of a girl in the same class as the pupil said he had gone to the school to complain before the man was removed and had contacted Suffolk Police to make a complaint that a grown man was “posing as a pupil” in her class.He said: “They logged my call and advised me to go back to the school and demand what action they were going to take,“I ended up speaking to this teacher who said that the Facebook picture of the boy was a case of mistaken identity.“The teacher actually threatened that all the parents who were jumping on the bandwagon could face legal action because complaining about the pupil was a criminal offence. He was basically calling all the parents bullies.“I explained that I was sorrythe pupil turned out to be a genuine -year-old, but that parents had a responsibility for the safeguarding of children in their care, as should the school.“The teacher told me that he had children himself and all the paperwork and been looked at for this person and had been passed by the Home Office. I was absolutely livid and was trying to behave myself.“He was so ignorant and not really listening to what I was saying. I wanted to kick him up the backside and tell him not to be so naïve. My last words to him were, “You have not heard the last about this”.Pupils became suspicious when they saw that the clean shaven pupil appeared to have the shadow of a beard on his face.They then discovered the Facebook profile in his name which described him as having been an architecture student at the Islamic Azad University in Abadan, Iran, before living in Erfurt, Germany.The pictures on the now deleted profile showed him with a beard and drinking a bottle of beer on a street, and also included an image of another -year-old boyIt was also claimed that the pupil bombarded a -year-old girl classmate with text messages, prompting her to complain to safeguarding staff – because she was worried about his true age.But the girl was told that there was nothing “sinister” about the texts as they were not of a sexual nature. When shown the alleged Facebook picture of the pupil with a beard, the teacher allegedly said that people matured at dferent ages. She stopped receiving messages from him after she complained.A mother of another pupil said the man had told her son that he was aged  and was married with two children when he was askedhe wanted to join in a game of football at break time.A Home Office spokesperson said: “When there is doubt about an inidual’s claim to be a child, the inidual will be referred to a local authority’s social services department for a careful, case law-compliant age assessment and they will be treated as a child until a decision on their age is made.“If an inidual is assessed to be over , we will process any asylum claim as being made by an adult. If the application is unsuccessful, and appeal rights are exhausted, removal action will be pursued as appropriate.“In the absence of documentary evidence, Home Office staff are only able to treat a claimant as an adulttheir physical appearance and demeanour very strongly suggest that they are signicantly over  years of age – and where two officers have reached this conclusion independently.“The threshold is set deliberately high so that only those who are very clearly over  are assessed as adults.”The pupil was removed from the school earlier this month on the day he was due to sit a mock GCSE maths exam and has not been seen there since.The Ormiston Academies Trust confirmed at the time that the pupils were “not attending the school” and that it had asked the Home Office to investigate the case.The school has not made any new statement and Suffolk County Council has also not responded to requests for comment.

title: scrooge school christmas commercial
story: Pupils at Lady Lumley’s School in Pickering, North Yorks., were told they must write to their RE teacher to plead for the celebration to be brought back.In an assembly this week, Father Christmas told students about the true meaning of Christmas being “lost and buried under an avalanche of commercialisation” before announcing the holiday was cancelled.Cards, gts and Christmas activities were banned unless persuasive arguments can be made to argue the real meaning of Christmas, he said.Children at the secondary school now have until November  to email their Religious Education teacher to persuade her the school should celebrate Christmas.Headteacher Richard Bramley said: “In assemblies this week, Mrs Paul, one of our teachers of RE, spoke about Christmas and whether the message of Christmas has been lost and buried under an avalanche of commercialisation.“Christmas is a day celebrating the birth of Jesus and should be a time of goodwill to all, yet it can be a very stressful, expensive, argumentative and lonely time.“Mrs Paul read out a letter from Father Christmas and cited the example of Christmas cards which bear no relation to the origin or meaning of Christmas but carry symbols we now recognise as associated with the holiday season, e.g Santa Claus who, in his modern incarnation, was probably invented by the Coca Cola company!The reception has been mixed among parents and students with the ban being taken badly by some.One parent tweeted: “I understand the way the RE teacher is trying to educate the kids. But its the way the kids have been told... Mine came in upset.Another user wrote: “@LadyLumleys what’s all this about kids not being able to celebrate Christmas  Is this a p***take or what! !”Others have endorsed the scheme.Alison Wilson said: “Dont know the details, but this actually sounds like quite a good exercise - getting everyone to actually think about what Christmas really is and why we should celebrate it.”Another user said: “Its far too commercial now,  months of brainwashing, I cant wait until its over.”Lfy wrote: “Mrs P did this at Bishopsgarth School and the parents said the same kind of thing. It is a brilliant idea.“As an RE teacher Mrs P is trying to get the pupils to understand what Christmas is really about ........ family and friends and caring for each other rather than Xboxes and Playstations.“For some families, especially those living in poverty, Christmas is a horrible time of year.

title: anglo saxon helmet worn brit military experts rebuild
story: Fragments of the golden headpiece, believed to have been worn by a general on the battlefields of Britain , years ago, were among a .m hoard uncovered by an amateur metal detectorist in Hammerwich, Staffordshire in .The invaluable helmet had been smashed into , fragments - presumably as the result of a fierce and bloody battle.Now two incredible replicas will go on display to the public after an -month project after experts felt it would be impossible to reconstruct it using the original pieces.One replica will go on permanent display at Birmingham Museum and Art Gallery and the other at the Potteries Museum and Art Gallery in Stoke-on-Trent.Weighing in at three kilograms each, the helmets are made out of steel, leather, gold, and silver plated bronze and copper.An expert from Birmingham Museums Trust said that one of the helmets was violently torn apart before burial.The Anglo-Saxons were made up of tribes from Germany, Denmark and the Netherlands.They inhabited England - which they called Angle-land - from around AD to , after the Romans soldiers left in .As well as being craftsmen and farmers, the Anglo-Saxons were also fierce warriors and would fight to the death to defend their territory.The Anglo-Saxons ruled Britain from  years when they were conquered by the Normans, who invaded from Northern France.The helmets were transformed using cutting-edge technology and ancient craft techniques and will go on display with other items found in the  hoard.A spokeswoman from Birmingham Museums Trust said substantial remains of just five other Anglo-Saxon helmets exist, along with fragments of a handful more - making them very rare.The quality, style and decoration of the Staffordshire Hoard helmet make it fit for a king, but we cannot be sure who it belonged to, she said.The original helmet was thoroughly, even violently, torn apart before burial, possibly more than was necessary to dismantle it for al reasons.

title: caged mink foxes and raccoon dogs driven to cannibalism at horrific fur farms linked to top british brands
story: Despite the atrocious injuries suffered by some of the animals, the farms were endorsed by a supplier linked with some of Britain’s top luxury brands.Investigators told The Independent of deplorable conditions and animal suffering at two centres in Finland certied by fur industry chiefs as “high welfare”.They revealed their findings to pressure UK government ministers to ban imports and sales of real fur.Investigators said the farms, chosen at random and filmed last month, indicated the true standards in the industry.One of the fur centres in question housed an estimated , mink.Footage shows foxes with “deformed feet and diseased eyes, and mink with open infected wounds, some even driven to cannibalism”, according to Humane Society International .The investigators said they saw an animal being gnawed at by its cellmate.Britain banned fur farming in  on humane grounds, but since then almost £m of fur has been imported, including £m worth from Finland.Much of it originally came from China, the US, France, Italy and Poland.Now environment secretary Michael Gove has been called on to stop the “double standard” and ban fur sales outright.Claire Bass, director of HIS UK, said: “It’s sickening that the fur trade still attempts to justy this blatant animal suffering, and we hope our investigation will encourage designers still using this fur to see through the travesty of so-called ‘high-welfare fur’.At another farm housing around , silver foxes, racoon dogs and Arctic foxes, the investigators said they saw animals showing signs of overfeeding – a tactic used to increase the amount of fat and fur on each one.A growing number of designers and retailers are dropping fur.This year Gucci, Versace, Michael Kors, Jimmy Choo, DKNY, Coach and Burberry have announced fur-free policies.London Fashion Week also made history with its first ever fur-free event.Rights groups say a lack of labelling tricks some shoppers into buying real fur when they think they are buying fake.The fur supplier said it instructed the farmers to arrange for vets to visit both farms after the footage emerged.It claimed the injured animals had purposefully isolated, and were awaiting treatment during the filming.Johanna Korpela, a veterinarian for the Finnish Fur Breeders’ Association said: The symptoms that some animals had in photos are regrettable and everything has been done in daily care routines to prevent such. But as in all animal farming, there will be the rare occasion when sicknesses or wounds etc. can occur.“Although responsible fur farmers are doing their best, it is possible that some of the thousands of production animals can suddenly fall ill. Four dead animals out of the , animals on the mink farm on the date of the secret filming equals .% mortality, which is below the typical figures in the production animal sector.”The statement claimed both farms involved had valid Finnish Standards certication and both farms have been inspected according to this certication programme.British MPs debated a ban on fur imports in Parliament in June after a petition garnered , signatures.In the end the government dismissed the idea, saying “national bans are less effective than working at an international level on animal-welfare standards”.Labour has pledged to ban fur imports and require real fur to be clearly labelled.

title: vladimir putin power launch nuke strikes plans russian parliament
story: Senators have recommended tearing up the military doctrine banning initial use of weapons of mass destruction.It comes after the Russian president said Moscow would retaliatethe US withdrew from a landmark cold War missile treaty.Currently the doctrine prohibits first use unless Russia is threatened by weapons of mass destruction orits very existence is in jeopardy.But the revision would give Putin power to order strikes in response to enemy use of conventional weapons, reports The Times.Senators in the Federation Council propose that Russia should be allowed to hit back with nuke weaponsthe country is attacked by hypersonic and non-nuclear strategic weapons.The move comes after Donald Trump announced that the US plans to withdraw from Intermediate-Range Nuclear ForcesTreaty signed by Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev in .Russia and America have accused each other of violating the deal, with the matter expected to be discussed by Trump and Putin at a G meeting in Argentina.The Kremlin warned that the US decision would make the world “a more dangerous place”.The Times reported that Franz Klintsevich, a member of the council’s defence committee, said that eastern European countries hosting Nato military bases, such as Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, “should understand that we won’t simply look at that through our fingers — we will react”.Konstantin Kosachev, the head of the council’s foreign committee, said that the US intention to withdraw from the treaty could lead to Russia deploying missiles banned by the pact “on the territories of our allies”.The move comes after the Pentagon updated its own nuclear policies by broadening the circumstances under which it would carry out nuclear strikes.Only last month, Putin told an international policy forum that Russia would only use its nuclear weapons in response to a nuclear attack on the country.He told the Valdai Club: “Our strategy of nuclear weapons use doesn’t envision a preemptive strike.Our concept is a launch under attack. Only when we become convinced that there is an incoming attack on the territory of Russia, and that happens within seconds, only after that we would launch a retaliatory strike.”

title: single mums on universal credit could jump the queue and get extra handouts amber rudd says
story: The new Work and Pensions boss says she would review the five-week wait, payments for housing, and repayment of loans in a sure sign that more changes are on the way.But she said she wanted to focus on the impacts on particularly single mothers.In an interview with Sky News she said: Im going to specically look at how Universal Credit impacts women... Im going to make sure thatwe need to make changes to support them then we will.Research has shown that single mums and women generally are some of the hardest hit by the Universal Credit and welfare system.The flagship policy, which is set to roll six benefits into one, has been beset with issues, but the new DWP boss has vowed to fix them.She insisted that the system was a force for good but admitted there were real problems that needed to be dealt with.Millions more Brits are set to go onto the new system in the coming months, as ministers transfer people from the old to the new system.Yesterday MPs demanded it be put back while ministers fix the problems with the scheme as it stands.Influential politicians on the Work and Pensions Committee demanded extra payments for those transferring over, a scrapping of the five week wait for people already on benefits, and moves to try and transfer vulnerable people over automatically.Ms Rudd said she wanted to make sure women are protected and have access to split paymentsthey are in domestic abuse relationships.She said: We need to give [claimants] more confidence in the fact that they can access cash immediately.You know people are nervous about moving from legacy benefits to Universal Credit because they cannot afford quite often to be without cash for a few days, a week, two weeks, three weeks.I have to make sure that they can have confidence in access in earlier.Ms Rudd said in the Commons earlier this week she would talk to the Treasury about extra cash for the department.Chancellor Philip Hammond revealed a package of measures in last months Budget to help those on Universal Credit - with a multibillion pound programme.Brits will be able to keep £ of what they earn and will get help with extra payments and debt management, but those arent set to come in for years.Apply for an advance - Claimants are able to get some cash within five days rather than waiting weeks for their first payment. But its a loan which means the repayments will be automatically deducted from your future Universal Credit pay out.Alternative Payment Arrangements- If youre falling behind on rent, you or your landlord may be able to apply for an APA which will get your payment sent directly to your landlord. You might also be able to change your payments to get them more frequently, or you can split the paymentsyoure part of a couple.Budgeting Advance - You may be able to get help from the government to help with emergency household costs of up to £youre single, £youre part of a couple or £you have children. These are only in cases like your cooker breaking down or for help getting a job. Youll have to repay the advance through your regular Universal Credit payments. Youll still have to repay the loan, evenyou stop claiming for Universal Credit.Cut your Council Tax - You might be able to get a discount on your Council Tax or be entitled to Discretionary Housing Paymentsyour payments arent enough to cover your rent.Foodbanks - If youre really hard up and struggling to buy food and toiletries, you can find your local foodbank who will provide you with help for free. You can find your nearest one on the Trussel Trust website.The current scheme is running five years behind schedule, and now wont cost any less than the old one.Brits have said it is pushing them into debt and some are struggling to survive - with one woman even saying she was forced to take £ for sex work while she waited.Yesterday a man who had his payments slashed said he was made to live on pasta and gravy.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: The annual photo Contest honours photographers who have captured jaw-dropping shots of landscapes, wildle and people from around the world.Among this years stunning entries is a cute picture of two bear cubs cuddling in long grass in Lake Clark National Park, Alaska.Also included is a photograph taken at night of a mountain in Australia, with haunting faces visible in the rock.
