title: council grinch christmas crackers children save cash
story: Aberdeen City Council is the latest to withdraw the festive gts from schools in order to save £, a year and reduce waste.The traditional items have until now been handed out to pupils during Christmas lunches at schools across the city.Opposition politicians have been quick to contrast the potential saving with the money being spent on the city’s Christmas Village – said to be around £,.Aberdeenshire Council already stopped handing out crackers about a decade ago while Moray Council discontinued the practice three years ago – though neither could say how much the policy saved taxpayers.Highland Council’s catering service does not provide crackers but inidual schools can purchase them, using their own budgets,they so wish.The Aberdeenshire authority came under fire last year for considering scrapping Christmas presents to care home residents to save £,.North-east Liberal Democrat MSP Mike Rumbles admitted he was disappointed by the decision but highlighted the funding issues facing Aberdeen and other councils.He said: “It is well known that Aberdeen City Council is the worst-funded local authority in Scotland, followed by Aberdeenshire, which is the third worst.“If it gets any worse, councillors will barely be able to keep the lights on.”But Aberdeen opposition SNP councillor Alex Nicoll said: “It sounds very much like the administration are playing the Grinch this year and that’s simply not on.“Surely it’s not too much to let pupils in our city get a simple Christmas cracker.”A spokesman for the Aberdeen council said: “Christmas lunch is a popular date on the school calendar and thousands of children across the city will enjoy a festive meal this year as part of the celebrations.“The decision has been taken not to provide crackers this year, which will reduce waste and contribute to financial efficiencies which ensure spending aligns with council priorities.”A Moray Council spokesman said: “The issue of crackers centrally for school Christmas lunches was stopped three years ago as part of a raft of measures to reduce catering costs, savings that could be implemented without affecting the quality of school meals.”A Highland Council spokesman said: “Highland Council’s school catering service does not provide crackers so there is no money spent or saved from the catering budget on crackers.“We have a devolved school management and therefore cannot provide comment on what our schools do inidually.”

title: face mum speaking grave christmas advert revealed
story: Natalie Martins gave the poignant voice over as a man listens to a tape of his tragic mother’s final loving Christmas message.The short film, Love is a Gt, by videographer Phil Beastall, has racked up more than million views this week, and has been dubbed better than John Lewis heavyweight ad.Natalies moving message of motherly love saw actor Chris Ilston weep as his character heard his beloved mums voice once more after opening a box of old cassettes.The award winning actress has been in seven feature films,  short films, numerous TV shows and adverts and some music videos.She was in Missing Edge, which won Best Film at the  Sci-Fi London Film Festival, and took home the Best Actress award for Miracle Grow at the London Independent Film Festival , among other awards.As Love is a Gt went viral, Natalie posted: Oh my word! Love is a Gt has now hit the million view mark.All the feels around the nation! Thanks to everyone who is sharing out short film.A special film with a special message.Congratulations Phil Beastall on this achievement - this didnt happen by chance or sheer luck - this happened because you are a talented filmmaker and a wonderful storyteller.Good work deserves to be seen - you deserve this.And she added last night: Our no budget film seems to be receiving all the love and stealing some thunder!The nation has been left weeping this week after the film, shot in , resurfaced and reminded people of the true message of Christmas.Chris, who has since gone on to co-found COBA Digital, posted today: A short film I was a part of  years ago seems to have gained huge traction in the past hrs, created by the talented Phil Beastall - and although I’m pleased to say my appearance has changed for the better - the message is still as relevant now as it was then.Since the emotional tale went viral, Phil has been inundated with messages from fans who claim the video could have been used instead of the expensive Elton John-themed John Lewis advert.Others have suggested the store hire him to make their Christmas ad for .Among those welling up after viewing the ad was Good Morning Britain host Ben Shephard who admitted on todays show he couldnt watch it without crying.The young filmmaker told the show he got the moving idea for the film while on a run.He said: To be honest, it was just a last minute decision really. Im a bit of a kind of frustrated film maker and I wanted to get a Christmas film out there.It was just when I was on a run on a Sunday and I just came up with this idea and I just really wanted to create something that would resonate with people as I thought especially in todays society we kind of just need that reminder that we are not really defined by our careers and materialism, actually family does come first.So ultimately I just wanted to create something that was emotive and what resonated with people and maybe they would turn to their wives, husbands, kids whatever and give them a cuddle and say I love you.Phil, from Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire, said he was a fan of the John Lewis ad, but added: “People seem to like my film because it’s the story that shines through. You don’t always need a huge budget, just an impactful narrative that gets the message across.”Thousands of commentators praised the video online and admitted that it had reduced them to tears.Melanie Thomas wrote: In tears. I have no words except John Lewis, tell your advertising team they [are] sacked. “Stop plugging Elton Johns song and get this man to do your adverts.Lisa Darling said: Best advert ever, maybe John Lewis should pay him a million.The response was so overwhelming that Phil conceded defeat in trying to respond to all the comments because the video attracted so much attention.Most touchingly, Phil received messages of thanks from parents who have lost a child and also children whose parents are no longer alive because the video had a positive impact on them.Phil said: “A lot of people are saying how it has touched them and made them feel that they can cope a little bit more this Christmas, which is amazing.“I never expected that at all. To think people are getting so much from my film.“I am blown away.”Phil made the video in  but was inspired to share it again now after seeing the Elton John advert on TV.The John Lewis advert cost £million to make, a fortune compared to the small budget production Love is a Gt, which cost less than £.Professional videographer Phil dedicated the emotive and video to the selflessness of his partner of ten years Claire Higley, the mother of their children Ethan, Eliza and Zara.The man in the video has to finally let go of his mother on the most family-orientated of days and Phil wanted to celebrate the le that has rewarded him with his we and mother to his children.John Lewis declined to comment.

title: benefits freeze state pension 2019
story: From April Brits will see their benefit payments from the government frozen yet again, but the state pension will go up by £. a week from to £. - a £ boost.The Tories triple lock means that pensions have to rise in line with inflation, earnings growth of . per cent - whichever is highest.This year that was . per cent, measured through the average rise in wages.The old state pension will rise from £. to £..Brits on maternity pay will see a slight boost from £. a week to £..But for most Brits who are claiming any kind of benefits - including Jobseekers Allowance, Income Support or Housing benefit, the rates will stay the same.The majority of working age benefits have been frozen at the   levels, meaning they wont get hiked in line with inflation.Ministers have faced calls to end the benefits freeze, with experts saying it will list , out of poverty.Senior Tories said Mrs May should end it or it will suffer at the ballot box when the next election comes around.Full time carers and benefits which are linked to disability will get a . per cent boost.Payments for people on Universal Credit will stay the same - but a boost to the work allowances that the Chancellor announced in the Budget will come into play.This rise of £ will mean Brits will keep an extra £ of what they earn in a year.

title: japan earthquake near fukushima nuclear power plant
story: The tremor is believed to be around . on the Richter scale and hit just over an hour ago.So far no major damage or injuries have been reported, and no tsunami warning has been issued.Fukushima is the capital city of Fukushima Prefecture, Japan, and was subject to a nuclear disaster in .It is in the norther part of Nakadori, the central region of the prefecture.On March , , an earthquake and tsunami occurred, with the earthquake affecting the citys water supply.Train infrastructure was also severely damaged, and an energy accident took place at the citys Daiichi nuclear power plant.This caused several explosions and the release of radioactive material.A frozen soil barrier was constructed to prevent ongoing exposure of running groundwater with melted-down nuclear fuel.More to follow...For the latest news on this story keep checking back at Sun Online.Thesun is your go to destination for the best celebrity news, football news, real-le stories, jaw-dropping pictures and must-see video.Download our fantastic, new and improved free App for the best ever Sun Online experience. title: theresa mays brexit deal branded sell out
story: She outlined the rough terms of a future trade deal in a -page political declaration — but also revealed that a post-Brexit transition deal could be extended until December .That is two years longer than originally suggested and would cost Britain an estimated £million for every month — on top of the £billion orce bill we must already pay to leave the EU.The agreement also leaves Britain tied to the hated European Court of Justice, which will still have the final say on any dispute over EU rules.The revelations incensed MPs who were already outraged by the concessions Britain has made. Former Tory leader Iain Duncan Smith said: “The last thing we want is for Britain to be tied beyond .“The British people want us to get out. This is a sell-out.”Former Brexit Secretary David Davis said: “This is £billion for a pig in a poke.“The EU’s got nailed down everything it wants whilst leaving us on a half promise of what we want.”And Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn called it “ pages of waffle”.He said: “The only certainty contained within these pages is that the transition period will have to be extended or we will end up with backstop and no exit.“It represents the worst of all worlds, no say over the rules that will continue to apply and no certainty to the future.”He accused the PM of producing a “blindfold Brexit from a government that spent more time negotiating with itself than for the nation”.In yesterday’s document, the EU agreed the UK can end free movement, try to negotiate deals with the rest of the world and take back control of fisheries.But the EU refused to accept that a future EU-UK trade deal will allow Mrs May “frictionless trade” and insisted the UK will be bound by EU rules on everything from state aid to climate change.And it only accepted that technology would be “considered” as a way of preventing theof a hard border in Irelanda future trade deal is not agreed.The terms will almost certainly be formally agreed by Mrs May and  other EU leaders at a crunch summit in Brussels on Sunday. This will trigger the orce bill of up to £billion.In a fierce Commons exchange, the PM resorted to urging MPs to back the deal when it goes before the Commons because the public is bored.She insisted “Brexit is within our grasp” adding: “The British people want Brexit to be settled.“They want a good deal that sets us on course for a brighter future.“And they want us to come together as a country and to move on to focus on the big issues at home, like our NHS.”She once more ruled out the prospect of a second referendum.And Downing Street insisted it will never happen “while she is Prime Minister”.But Brexiteers lined up to slam the agreement — fuelling concerns it will never make it through the Commons in a critical “Meaningful Vote” in three weeks’ time.More than  Tories are thought to be ready to vote down the deal — alongside the DUP, SNP and most Labour MPs.Cabinet ministers spent much of a conference call with Mrs May ­yesterday morning debating how to sell the deal to the nation.Last night Chief Whip Julian Smith emailed Tory MPs urging them to “unite” and back the PM. He told backbenchers: “If we reject this deal we go back to square one.“This would mean damaging uncertainty which will threaten jobs, investment and the economy.”Home Secretary Sajid Javid insisted the deal “delivers on the referendum” — although he admitted the Government must do a “better job of selling” it.But Boris Johnson said the terms of the Brexit deal made a “complete nonsense of Brexit”.And Brexiteers warned they could not support a deal which still included the so-called Irish backstop plan for keeping the border open.But Mrs May insisted it would only kick ina new trade deal isn’t in place by January .But it is still just a woolly and even contradictory wishlist that barely binds Brussels to anything.The cost of these vague promises Some  thousand million pounds.This “political declaration” about the future is predicated on Brussels negotiating a trade deal in good faith, a ­quality they have never shown since the referendum result they are even now desperate to overthrow.Why would their puerile desire to “punish” Britain abate once we nominally leave next March  Especially when under the terms now agreed they can trap us in the Customs Union for ever The PM claims the EU wouldn’t want us there, benefiting from it for free, having ended free movement. But that’s a price Brussels will surely pay to cripple us as a trading rival on their doorstep.That said, the deal is NOT all bad.Downing Street rightly trumpets that it ends free movement and our massive membership subscription, protects jobs and secures our fishing rights .And Mrs May, to her considerable credit, pushed the EU into an extraordinary U-turn over a high-tech solution to police the Irish border. Remember how glibly they once sneered at that idea Trouble is, who trusts them not to change heart againthe appalling “Irish backstop” alternative suits them The trade deal may take years. Anyone could veto it: Spain over Gibraltar. Or the Belgian Walloons who almost wrecked the EU Canada deal. We would be stuck.And while Mrs May’s deal enshrines our right to an independent trade policy, it also says any new partnership with the EU must “build on” a single customs territory. That’s why Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab quit — it ­scuppers any deals where.The one straw we clutch is that Jeremy Corbyn isn’t negotiating. None of his scripted lines, nor his brow furrowed in supposed concentration, can hide that the entire debate sails over his head.Don’t imagine the chaos couldn’t be worseOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: rspca dog emaciated oscar stockport
story: Shocking pictures show American bulldog Oscar so think you can see all of his rubs under his skin.The poor pooch, seven, was found tied up at a busy junction in Stockport.RSPCA bosses are appealing for information after he was found at HALF his natural weight - .kg rather than kg.The abandoned pets original owner has been traced through his microchip.He was found at am on Monday, November , and rushed to a vets in Cheadle Hulme.Oscar is now in the care of the RSPCA, according the Manchester Evening News.Inspector Nadine Pengilly said he is literally a skeleton.She added: “He’s so emaciated.“In my  years as an RSPCA inspector, he’s the skinniest dog I have seen that wasn’t dead.He was  to  hours away from death.“He has used up all of his body fat and muscle – the next thing to have been used would have been his organs and that would have killed him.Oscar was treated on a drip for the first  hours.“He’s so hungry that when you take the plate away he just looks at you so sadly,” Nadine added.Oscars original owners told RSPCA investigators they had given him to an unnamed man in a park a year previous.“I would love to get them,” Nadine said.“Someone’s been sat there watching this happen to him.”

title: andrew griffiths faces no further
story: NewsAndrew Grfiths faces no further action from Tory chiefs over his , sex textsThe decision - which could allow the MP to rejoin the Tory whip - was taken over his mental health, but Conservative chiefs are accused of burying bad news with the timingShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsThe former business minister was hauled before a disciplinary committee "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailShamed MP Andrew Grfiths will face no further action from the Conservative Party over the , sex texts he sent to two barmaids.The former business minister was hauled before a disciplinary committee after his sadistic messages were revealed by the Sunday Mirror.But despite an inquiry finding he potentially broke the Conservative Partys code of conduct, party chiefs said he will face no further action. The decision has been taken due to the state of his mental health both now and at the time. It opens the door for the MP - who was suspended from the Tories during the investigation - to rejoin the party in Parliament. Critics accused Tory chiefs of burying the news yesterday while Theresa May launched a new push to get her Brexit deal through the Commons. Deneice Florence-Jukes, a councillor in East Staffordshire, claimed it was a get out jail free card while the government is hanging by a thread.  Married Mr Grfiths, , said he was deeply ashamed after the Sunday Mirror revealed he sent Imogen Treharne and her friend pound and offered to rent a flat to meet for sex. In a string of texts he called himself “Daddy”, promised moneyhe received racy images and said I want you to be really rough. One text described him making someone dress up like a pig while another said: Daddy’s busy running the country.He later said he was suffering from a ‘manic episode’ and then had a breakdown, spending  days in a psychiatric hospital. “The government has a suicide minister but I am not sure it knew how to handle a suicidal miniser. That needs to change,” he said. Mr Grfiths resigned as a minister but remained an independent MP after being suspended from the Tories. Chief Whip Julian Smith is now considering whether to readmit him to the Conservative whip.

title: high powered rifles ban quietly
story: NewsHigh-powered rles ban quietly dropped after DUP and Tories threaten to block itThe guns can immobilise a vehicle or truck from a mile away - but  MPs voiced their opposition including some from the DUPShareByMikey SmithPolitical reporter:,  NOV NewsDUP Westminster leader Nigel Dodds, left with leader Arlene Foster, signed the amendment "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Government has quietly dropped plans to ban high-powered rles after Tory Brexiteers and DUP MPs joined forces in defiance of Theresa May. Police say it would be impossible to defend against a terrorist with one of the . calibre or higher guns which can immobilise a vehicle or truck from a mile away. And the Government had the backing of the Labour Party to pass the ban through Parliament. But  MPs signed an amendment to reverse the ban, including members of Jacob Rees-Mogg’s European Research Groupof hard Brexit backbenchers. The group said the ban was disproportionate, and laid out plans for a high-security process for people to obtain high-energy weapons. Yet they were also seeking the chance to prove they had the numbers in Parliament to block government legislation in the run up to the ‘meaningful vote’ on Theresa May’s Brexit deal.  Former Brexit minister Steve Baker, Sir Bill Cash and Sir Bernard Jenkin were among those supporting the amendment to the offensive weapons bill that would prevent a ban on rles that have a power of “over , joules at the muzzle.” It was also opposed by DUP MPs and Labour MP Kate Hoey. Last week, the DUP effectively suspended their deal to prop up Theresa May’s minority in the Commons with votes. And tonight Home Secretary Sajid Javid quietly backed down, tabling an amendment that strips the ban from the bill ahead of a vote on Wednesday, therevealed. Louise Haigh MP, Labour’s Shadow Policing and Crime Minister, said: “It is staggering that the Government are so weak they can’t even pass laws to ban enormously powerful anti-truck and anti-tank rles. “Senior officers have warned the police have no known protection against these destructive weapons and yet Ministers have still caved into their restive backbenchers. “Labour will back our police on Wednesday and do everything we can to keep the ban in the Bill.”

title: insists shes not planning use
story: NewsMay insists shes not planning to use a stock market crash to ram through BrexitTheresa May was reportedly set to use MPs fears to get a Brexit deal through - but No said "absolutely not"ShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporterDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  NOV NewsCalm down, everyone"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May today insisted shes absolutely not planning to use a stock market crash to ram through her vision of Brexit. The Prime Minister was forced to deny shock claims she will take advantage of financial chaos to get her deal past MPs. Her deal faces being rejected in a House of Commons vote before Christmas - throwing Britain into chaos. She was reportedly considering a second votethe markets are spooked - and using the fear of a crash to change MPs minds. But today Downing Street insisted that was absolutely not Mrs Mays plan.  Askedthe government was preparing for a two-step approval process, where Mrs May goes to MPs a second time amid market chaos, a No spokeswoman said: Absolutely not. The Prime Minister will be focused on engaging widely with MPs, members of the public, employers and setting out why this is a good deal for the UK and why MPs should vote for it.” Frantic talks in Brussels continued today as  EU leaders prepare to sign off the Brexit deal at a summit on Sunday. Theresa May will meet EU chief Jean-Claude Juncker tomorrow in the Belgian capital after  pages of text were agreed. They’ll be discussing how to bring everything to a conclusion ahead of Sunday, a No spokeswoman said. The EU has agreed a two-part Brexit deal - and it has enraged Tories. Boris Johnson urged Tories to junk the deal and ex-Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab said it was worse than cancelling Brexit.  November : Emergency EU summit with  other leaders to sign off the deal. December : If theres a deal, this is when the transition period - which continues pretty much all the EU rules we have now - is supposed to end. But it could be extended by two more years.  January : If theres still no deal, under current plans a backstop would kick in. This could keep the UK tied to EU customs rules, until a proper agreement is reached, in exchange for keeping the Northern Ireland border open. Read the full guide to the timetable here. Even the pro-EU Confederation of British Industry, which lavished praise on the deal in public, admitted it was not good in leaked e-mails. Wine stockist Majestic is taking no chances - and is stockpiling a million bottlestheres no agreement by March . A No spokeswoman said: The withdrawal agreement isn’t being reopened. title: tory party dog days last
story: NewsopinionThe Tory Party is in its dog days - and they are the last ones to realiseIf democracy is to remain realistic we need the Tories to reviveShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  NOV Newsopinion"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The Tories are not wanted now, put out each one. Pack up Theresa and inform the Sun.Pour away the inept and sweep the dead wood. This party now can never come to any good. If theres one thing Western democracy has proven, it is that no-one can be trusted with power for very long.A first administration achieves change the second stagnates and a third,it appears, eats itself from the feet up. The same is true of every party, in every nation, and there is none among us who would be immune to the madness of power were it delivered for a third time.It sends all politicians who have ever managed it into the sort of cocaine-inspired bender Elton John was once famous for - trying to outdo Freddie Mercury with their own sense of misplaced grandeur, while actually being destined for a le in which they look forward to the John Lewis Christmas ad. It happened to Thatcher, it happened to Blair, and now its happening to the entire Conservative Party at once. This time its not a prime ministers career doomed to failure -  years of British politics is circling the plughole, entirely unaware of its looming extinction.   Over Thatchers time in office she burned every friend she had, endeared herself to half the country by presiding over an economic boom, and flushed middle-class goodwill down the toilet with the poll tax. Tory MPs with an eye to their own survival queued up to kne her as their only escape, and combined with the fact shed destroyed the other half of the country along with unions and manufacturing her time was nigh. Blair started out as a nice-sweatered saviour and came to believe he was genuinely touched by God, able to heal wars, depose despots with his righteousness and had no need to plan for the future because he was going to be raptured as soon as hed fixed the Middle East. He even tried to go one better than Jesus by cutting a deal with his personal Judas, and the net result was the whole Labour Party got stuck in the psychodrama and forgot they were supposed to be working for the people.Now we are in our eighth year of the Tories being in control, and theyve gone completely round the bend in half the time it took the others. Lets be kind. Theyve managed a fourth administration on a technicality, been presented with the most complex political problem in British history, and had the backwash of the Great Recession to deal with. But a party operating in the realms of sanity would not have called the fourth election, would not have attempted to settle centuries of squabbling with Europe by flipping a coin, or claimed to be fixing the economy by letting bankers keep their hands on the interestingly-smashy bits.The fact they were going round the twist so early in their reign is the surest sign this is the end game all decisions since  have been touched by madness, with the inevitable result that the Tories now think they really CAN lick their elbow because theyve spent so long claiming to be the only party you can trust with dficult stuff. Every economic, housing, health, justice and education policy did more to reduce than to improve them. This is not a political point but a factual one - the Tories have managed not one single victory, no shining achievement, in almost a decade of control. But there is a near-infinite number of turds. They deported British citizens in the Windrush scandal. They watched  people die in a towering inferno and sent benefit fraudsters to jail quicker than those who caused the deaths. Under their rule , people are thought to have needlessly died. An unprecedented rise in mortality has been linked directly to their policies. The greatest British invention of all time, the National Health Service, is being thoughtlessly destroyed for lack of maintenance. More than a million people are living in destitution and while they crow about near-full employment, millions of those in work rely on charity to feed their families.The Tories, whatever you may think of them, have never been so definitively linked to death and misery. If they had their wits about them, the backbenchers should, about now, be trying to dig their party out of this homicidal mire. Instead theyre declaring every disaster is someone s fault.  Having secured the countrys backing for Brexit, they spent two years arguing with themselves to the detriment of the British economy. Having secured the agreement of the EU on how to Brexit, they want to go back to negotiating it. And despite being called the Conservative and Unionist Party they seem prepared to throw Northern Ireland on the bonfire to appease their most eccentric members.They spent the first year of negotiations demanding Theresa May call an election to secure her mandate, and after she did so spent the second year demanding her head. The million letters of no confidence they cheerfully predicted turned into  they expected by pm, then definitely , then somewhere nearer . They dont even have confidence in their lack of confidence, and their only chance of passing a motion is with internal application of WD-. And while repeatedly calling themselves the party of law and order they let off their own sex pest because he says he was ill, when all sex pests in whatever courts remain open are sent down without mercy.Theyre now a minority government pretending theyre not, killing citizens while claiming to be acting in the national interest, and the only reason this rabid party hasnt been put out of its self-destructive misery is because the Opposition is too busy shooting itself in the foot.

title: helpless mum watched baby born
story: NewsHelpless mum watched baby born at  weeks gasp for air and claims doctors left her to dieWARNING: CONTAINS DISTRESSING IMAGES. Sophie Dennis says her daughter showed signs of le but claims doctors left her to dieShareCommentsByJames Somper:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsSophie says she put Autumn on her chest for two hours until she was gone "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum who lost her baby at just  weeks claims doctors gave up on her daughter and left her to die – because she was born before the abortion limit. Sophie Dennis, , claims little Autumn Orion Dennis showed signs of le and lived for nearly two hours after she was born in October  – before taking her final breaths in her mother’s arms. Sophie claims doctors at the Royal Victoria Infirmary in Newcastle told her they wouldnt be able to help Autumn because she was born so prematurely, but after the birth she showed signs of le an NHS report revealed ‘were not anticipated’ by doctors. The legal limit of viability – whether or not a baby is deemed to be capable of growing – is  weeks, the abortion limit.  Sophie, from Newcastle, said: “When Autumn was born, I pleaded with doctors to help her. “They said there was nothing they could do because she was  weeks – I think they were expecting her to be born stillborn. “I was in shock so I didn’t protest. They told me how disabled she would be and how she wouldn’t be fit for lethey helped her. “I said ‘are you going to leave my baby to die’ ” “Autumn came out gasping for air, and we kept asking them to do something.  “You could feel her pulse and feel her heartbeat. As she was passed to me she was moving and gasping for air. “She was placed on my chest. I cried as I held her for nearly two hours. “It was instant love but heartbreak at the same time. I felt like I’d failed her and kept apologising to her. I kept saying sorry to her. “Doctors didn’t help her because they were expecting a stillborn. “At the end of the day she was born showing signs of le so she should have been treated as such. “I felt like I wanted to get up and put her in an incubator myself but I also felt helpless. You can’t put it into words how it feels hold your child and watch her die in your arms.  “She was showered with love the whole time she was alive. I would have done anything to swap places with her. “Eventually, a midwe checked on her and said she was gone. “My heart broke and a piece of me left that night and went with her, a piece of me and the person I once was died that night and went with her.” Autumn was born at only  weeks and six days in October  following Sophie’s high risk pregnancy during which she was diagnosed with subchronic haematoma - blood clots in her tissue. An NHS report concluded that Sophie and her husband should have been given the opportunity to talk to a neonatologist regarding the options available and that Autumn was born showing some signs of le, which were not anticipated. NHS advice states that babies born between  and  weeks “may not survive or may have long- term problems” and the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologistssay that babies born within this period are a “a major medical and ethical challenge”.  The RCOG say that only after  weeks is there a general agreement that active management should be offered. Sophie also claims doctors made an error on her maternity notes, saying she was  weeks and one day pregnant, which resulted in her daughter not being viewed as ‘viable’. Sophie and husband Sam have now spoken out following the birth of miracle baby son Laken in earlier this year. Sophie said: “I was scared of losing Laken at certain milestones, but thankfully it was a textbook pregnancy “When he was born I didnt want to hold him straight away, I needed a minute because I was full of emotion. “Then something clicked and I scooped him up and held him close to me in the same place where I held Autumn. “I believe she’s always around us and that Autumn looked out for Laken while I was pregnant with him. But despite the joy of a new baby since Autumn’s birth, Sophie says that her baby’s death has devastated her and her family.  Sophie has now launched a petition in an effort to get the guidelines on assisting premature babies revised. She said: “I don’t think any mum should have to go through that level of emotional and physical pain and then be told there’s nothing they could do and watch their child die. “It’s currently a guideline to help a baby born under  weeks eventhey show signs of le. It’s so wrong. If a woman wants to have an abortion she can, buta woman wants her baby to survive they cant. “I knew on that bed, holding my child dying, that I’d do everything I could to stop that happening. “If parents want a child to be helped and the baby is born showing signs of le which Autumn was than they should, because that’s a basic human right. There was so much more that they could have done. I feel hugely let down by the NHS. They let me and my daughter down. I can’t even describe in words how I feel about how they treated us that night. An apology won’t put it right. If she’d have been helped then she would have had a chance at le. “The decision to try and keep my daughter alive was taken away from us and that was heartbreaking.”

story: NewsBlack Friday : UK high streets deserted but online tills are ringing in £.bn splurgeEmpty streets in city centres around the UK show that the real action is almost exclusively online thesedays - but is interest dropping in the whole phenomenon ShareCommentsByGavin AllenAssociate Editor:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsIt wasnt hard to get to the shops in Glasgow city centre this morning "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBritains biggest high streets and shops were quiet today as the hype around Black Friday failed to translate into footfall.On one of the biggest shopping days of the year - and what was become the starting gun for the Christmas shopping season -Brits are expected to spend pound. billion on deals in stores and online, according to predictions from the Centre for Retail Research.That sum would be down on the pound. billion splashed last year, suggesting that the days popularity may be waning already.Since Black Friday was adopted by Britons back in  the trend has been for high street shops to reduce instore bargains due to the chaos they brought.Amazon Prime worker Tessa Barrera tweeted this image of the queue outside the firms pop-up shop in Shoreditch, East London. Black Friday chaos around the world as frantic shoppers scramble for bargains The big business is done online.Thats where the queues lie today, with thousands of punters invisible to photographers, sat at home with their fingers hovering over mouse buttons ready to click up a bargain.Twitter user @technikyle from Manchester was told to wait  minutes before she could even enter the Game Website because she was number  in the online queue.Similar frustrations were experienced with @yrenia sat in an online queue. But despite signals that the day may be beginning to wane in popularity, a huge amount is still set to be spent.More than two fths of Britons are planning to spend in the Black Friday sales today amid warnings not to get carried away by the hype. A study by accountacy firm KPMG said % of Britons are looking forward to the event, and % are specically looking to buy Christmas presents - while % are intending to shop on Cyber Monday. Paul Martin, UK head of retail at KPMG, said: Retail performance throughout the year has been dreary to say the least, and weve certainly had a shaky start to the all-important golden quarter. Retailers will naturally be keen to make the most of these events, and our survey would certainly suggest that consumers are gearing up for it. However, consumer group Which  said its over-arching message to shoppers this year was to not feel pressured into spending after finding that nine in  Black Friday deals last year were the same price or even cheaper at other times of the year. It has urged consumers to be careful not to buy on impulse and instead research products and prices before spending in the sale. Alex Neill, Which  managing director of home products and services, said: While retailers are bombarding us with promises of great discounts and time-limited sales, its clear that not all deals are as good as they might appear. To bag a bargain, do your research and dont get carried away by the hype when shopping in the upcoming sales. Early indications suggest that Black Friday spending will dip for the first time this year since its arrival in the UK. Consumers will spend pound. billion on deals in stores and online, down from last years pound. billion, according to the predictions from the Centre for Retail Researchand VoucherCodes. Analyst Springboard has also said footfall and spending activity over this years Black Friday period is likely to be affected by economic pressures such as high debt levels and signicant living costs, compounded by the event taking place a week earlier this year - before many consumers are paid for the month. According to KPMGs study, the promotional period is favoured by younger consumers, with % of shoppers aged  to  saying they will be taking advantage of deals compared to % of  to  year olds, and just % of over s. Mr Martin added: Many shoppers are likely to recall how the slashed pricing in store resulted in stampedes, which is just not what mature consumers seek out. Since Black Friday was adopted by Britons back in , retailers have increasingly moved offers online, and that coincidentally is where a higher proportion of younger consumers can be found.

story: NewsFirst picture of -year-old GCSE pupil in Ipswich school CONFIRMED to be adultThe asylum seeker has been removed from Stoke High School, officials said, as they confirmed he is over the age of ShareByAdam Theofilatos:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsThe student has been removed from the school "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn asylum seeker posed as a -year-old student at a school in Ipswich, an investigation has revealed.The man - thought to be aged around  - was removed from the school after it was confirmed he is over the age of . Suspicions were aroused amongst fellow pupils because of his mature looks, which included his full beard and ft height. He spent six weeks at Stoke High School in Ipswich, Suffolk apparently as a Year  student. The Home Office has not confirmed how old the man is, however a classmate previously said: It’s like someone’s dad has come into school.  “He’s got a big beard, while the other boys I know are struggling to grow little moustaches. He’s very tall, around ft I’d say. “When I heard he was actually  years old I immediately told my mum.” Immigration services said that the pupil was assessed and is over  following investigation ordered by the Home Office. The man is now being treated an adult asylum seeker and could be thrown out of the UKhis claim is refused. It is believed that the asylum seeker sought a place at a secondary school after failing to find work because his qualications were not recognised. Horried parents pulled their children from the school in protest after the Snapchat image of the man appeared in the media. The image of the pupil, taken by another boy, was accompanied by the caption: “How is there a  year old man in our maths class. One mum said at the time: Looking at photos of this man, he is clearly older than . My son has always said that he looks older. I wont have my son studying with a -year-old man.   The student was subsequently removed from the school following the outrage. The Home Office declared that the mans physical appearance and demeanour show that he is clearly over the age of . A Home Office spokesman said: We are fully committed to safeguarding children and are looking into the circumstances of this case to understand how it was handled. Age-disputed cases remain a challenging area of work in which no single assessment technique, or combination of techniques, is likely to determine an iniduals age with precision. In the absence of clear and credible documentary evidence, Home Office staff must rely on physical appearance and demeanour to make an initial assessment on whether a person claiming to be a child is under . If an inidual is assessed to be under , but subsequent concerns about their age are raised - for example by a school - we will act quickly to reconsider the case. The man, believed to be around  started at Stoke High School which is run by the Ormiston Academies Trust in September. His younger brother, believed to be a year seven student has also been taken out of class but the Home office confirmed that he is a child.  The Home Office spokesperson added: When there is doubt about an iniduals claim to be a child, the inidual will be referred to a local authoritys social services department for a careful, case law-compliant age assessment and they will be treated as a child until a decision on their age is made. If an inidual is assessed to be over , we will process any asylum claim as being made by an adult. If the application is unsuccessful, and appeal rights are exhausted, removal action will be pursued as appropriate. In the absence of documentary evidence, Home Office staff are only able to treat a claimant as an adulttheir physical appearance and demeanour very strongly suggest that they are signicantly over  years of age - and where two officers have reached this conclusion independently. The threshold is set deliberately high so that only those who are very clearly over  are assessed as adults.

story: NewsMans tear-jerking £ Christmas film is so popular people want John Lewis to hire himPhil Beastall has brought millions of people to tears with a short film about how it feels to have lost a loved one during the festive seasonShareCommentsByRobyn DarbyshireAudience Writer:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video fans-tear-jerking-christmas-video-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFans of a tear-jerking Christmas viral video made for just pound are calling for John Lewis to hire the budget filmmaker for their next festive advert. The budget festive film racked up more than five million views on Facebook this week after filmmaker Phil Beastall posted it in response to the stores poundmillion big budget production starring Elton John. He wrote: Off the back of the John Lewis Christmas advert I wanted to share my very own Christmas film which I made back in . Its a short film about a man counting down the days to Christmas so he can continue his yearly tradition sparked by a tragic moment from the past. The -year-olds video, entitled Love is a Gt, shows a man ticking off the days to Christmas, seemingly in anticipation of festivities and presents.   Instead, on the day he opens up a cassette box - an annual tradition - and listens to a tape of his tragic mother’s final Christmas message from beyond the grave. Since the emotional tale went viral, Phil has been inundated with messages from fans who claim the video could have been used instead of the expensive Elton John-themed John Lewis advert. Thousands of people praised the video online and admitted that it had reduced them to tears. One said: In tears. I have no words except John Lewis, tell your advertising team they [are] sacked. Stop plugging Elton Johns song and get this man to do your adverts. Another said: Best advert ever, maybe John Lewis should pay him a million. Most touchingly, people who have lost loved ones have commented to say that the film has resonated with them.   One Facebook user wrote: It will be my th Christmas without my mum x it’s always gut wrenching every year... Its a sad lonely time for a lot of people. Phil, from Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire, said: A lot of people are saying how it has touched them and made them feel that they can cope a little bit more this Christmas, which is amazing. I never expected that at all. To think people are getting so much from my film. I am blown away. Other social media users have suggested the store hire Phil to make their Christmas advert for .   Phil said: People seem to like my film because its the story that shines through. You don’t always need a huge budget, just an impactful narrative that gets the message across. I think theres a bit of a revolution going on in the advertising industry. People no longer want to be overtly sold something which makes our job as video producers a lot harder because we have to sell indirectly. Phil said that although he enjoyed John Lewis advert, he thinks spending so much on an advert when people struggle financially isnt sitting well with people.   ButJohn Lewis knocked on my door tomorrow and said would you want to make next year’s film I would obviously snap it up in an instant. The aim of the film is to encourage people to reflect on whats around them and how lucky we are for the things we have. Everyone just needs a bit of love in their le and we should all try to look after each other. Professional videographer Phil dedicated the emotive and video to his partner of ten years Claire Higley, the mother of their children Ethan, Eliza and Zara.has contacted John Lewis for comment.

story: NewsTrophy hunting firm slammed for £k wildle killing trips in UK countrysideHunters might have to pay to £, for a world-record class animal with smaller fees between £, and £,ShareCommentsByJames Murray:,  NOV NewsAt the heart of the operation are Texan Aaron Bulkley, and Englishman Alex Hinkins, a well known deer stalker "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailProtesters are blasting a trophy hunting firm which organises heartless wildle killings in the English countryside for up to pound,. At the heart of the operation is Texan Aaron Bulkley, , and Englishman Alex Hinkins, a well known UK deer stalker. On his website Europehunts, Mr Bulkley boasts: “What we have in England are some species you can’t hunt anywhere  in the wild or estate. “We have some of the largest red stag, the world record Chinese water deer, the Muntjac. This really is a destination for hunters to fulfil some European slams.”   A “world record class animal” can cost pound,. The fee for shooting a smaller red stags falls in stages from pound,, to pound,, to pound,, right down to pound,. Accommodation, flights and meals are extra. On the website is a picture of a man holding the horns of a huge animal, with a telescopic sight over its neck. A caption reads: “New world record red stag in England. Aaron and guests hunted  days in Woburn [Beds] and Norfolk. It was in Norfolk they put down some monster fallow deer.” Woburn Abbey was quick to distance itself, saying: “It is highly likely this party was hunting in the Woburn area with no connection to the Bedford Estates.”  Mr Bulkley boasts on the website that he has been awarded “guide of the year”and “outfitter of the year” titles many times. But Europehunts’s brazen selling has appalled animal lovers.Chris Luffingham, of the League Against Cruel Sports, says: “It is sickening to know that trophy hunting is taking place here in the heart of the UK.” The pressure group Bedfordshire Against Trophy Hunting started a petition to try and get the hunting stopped. It said: “This is a disgrace and should be investigated by Parliament.” Mr Bulkley and Mr Hinkins made no comment.

story: NewsFlight attendants reveal their odd use for sanitary towels on planesEmily Witkop has explained how she can use a sanitary towel to solve a common problemShareCommentsByRobyn DarbyshireAudience Writer:,  NOV NewsThe hack must be happy when things get turbulent "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFlight attendants have to help passengers as part of their job, which can sometimes be dficult when things get messy. title: tragic mystery three siblings who
story: NewsTragic mystery of three siblings who vanished on beach trip never to be seen againThe case of the three missing children and the unidentied tall, blond man gripped Australia and the world when the youngsters vanished in ShareCommentsByAbigail OLeary:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsPictured right to left, Jane, nine, Arnna, seven, and Grant, four - all vanished on January , "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhat should have been a sun-drenched day trip for three children at the beach ended in a family being torn apart - and two parents forced to live with the unimaginable grief of their disapparance. The case of the missing Beaumont children and the unidentied tall, blond man gripped Australia and the wider world after the youngsters mysteriously vanished in . Jane, nine, Arnna, seven, and Grant, four, left their family home on January  and headed for Glenelg Beach near Adelaide in the south of the country. Their mum Nancy stuffed a total of six shillings into their pockets for bus fare and lunch and waved them goodbye. That was the last time she, and her husband Jim, would ever see their young children again. Nancy, now , expected them tohome at midday, and became worried when they still hadnt shown up when Jim arrived home from work at around pm.   Two hours later, the frantic parents reported the children missing - unaware they were about to enter a decades-long hunt for their children. Within  hours, news of their disappearance had spread across Australia and reports came in of them last being seen with a tall blond man who seemed in his mid s, reports MammaMia. Witnesses said they had seen the children playing on the beach with the man, before they later went to a nearby bakery to buy lunch. Suspicions of the man they were spotted with soon grew into fears they had been abducted, after it emerged they used a pound note to buy pasties for themselves and an extra meat pie for an unknown person.   Nancy told police she had not given them any notes on the morning they left home and that her children never ate meat pies. Police believed this indicated the unidentied fair-headed man was still with the children at the time they bought lunch. As the police search escalated, detectives desperately searched for some of the  items they had on the persons at the time - including clothing, towels and a bag. Despite their best efforts, not of these items were ever recovered. The case even saw a Dutch psychic Gerard Croiset being flown in to help track down the children and bring up any potential leads.  Two days after first being reported missing, their mum Nancy had become so traumatised by their disappearance, she was put under sedation by a doctor. Five days later after the children left home, their father Jim made an emotional plea to anyone who may have or know where the children were. In the following weeks and months, the heartbroken parents retreated from the public eye and cut off all connection with the media. Earlier this year, fresh leads led police to search a factory in North Plympton, but the dig only found animal bones.  Chief superintendent Des Bray said: There has been nothing human located on the site. Sadly, this means for the Beaumont family that we still have no answers. Over the years, police released computer generated images of the children and how they may look having aged. It was widely reported Nancy never once looked at the images and was traumatised every time an updated CGI image was released In the early s, Nancy and Jim split up and sold the home they desperately hoped their children would one dayto.

title: ufo hunter shares pictures real
story: NewsUFO hunter shares pictures of real-le ALIEN skull with two separate layersLi Jianmin made the astonishing revelation at a seminar - but admitted no DNA tests have yet been done on the skullShareCommentsByTim Wyatt:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsThe brown object is said to be double-layered, unlike human skulls "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA science fiction author and amateur UFO hunter claims he has got hold of an alien skull. Li Jianmin, , made the astonishing revelation at a seminar in the Chinese capital Beijing. He said the skull was brown in colour and about cm in diameter, according to local media. Unlike human skulls, the supposed extraterrestrial one had two dferent layers, he added. The other-worldly artact originally came from a street seller in the Inner Mongolia region and was bought by a private collector. The buyer was then reading one of Lis sci-fi novels when he came across an illustration of an alien skull which looked remarkably like the one he had just bought.   Mutant starfish discovered on the ocean floor leaves scientists dumbstruck After the collector got in touch with Li, the UFO enthusiast spent four months examining the find. He has now produced a -page study in a bid to provide evidence that the skull is in fact from outer space. Li said he had used high-tech scientic methods to test the skull.He carried out Raman spectroscopy - which creates a fingerprint to identy which exact molecules are present in a sample - and atomic force microscopy, a technique which can see things  times smaller than ordinary microscopes.   He then compared his findings with other supposed alien skulls discovered where in the world. But when asked by reporters, Li admitted he had not yet done a DNA test, which could provethe cranium is actually from a creature on Earth. Paying for DNA analysis is around , yuan, he said, which is about pound,.   The author has been widely mocked on social media for his wild claims, but remains convinced the skull is real. I welcome questions and scepticism, butyou decide to challenge me, be sure to bring along evidence, he said.

title: bournemouth ace fraser believes united squad can propel scotland to euro 2020
story: Winger Ryan Fraser says the “togetherness” of the Scotland squad can propel them to Euro  qualication – without the need for a play-off.The Bournemouth man took his impressive club form in the English Premier League on to the international stage in the wins over Albania and Israel by grabbing his first goal for his country in the Balkans before setting up the third goal in the - home win over the Israelis.Alex McLeish’s squad, after a number of call-offs, has a youthful feel to it these days and Fraser says that has its good points and bad points.He said: “In patches the lack of experience shows how it can be good and in patches it shows how it can be bad.“We did well to go - up and then there was a little bit of inexperience to concede the goal and then it was nervous at the end.“It’s not nice in that sense – but everyone being young and ambitious helps with people going forward and scoring goals.“I think we scored more goals in the two games than Scotland have scored for a while.“Hopefully, that can help get the fans off their seatswe’re playing expansive football.“It was a bad startand it took a lot of character and was a big test to come through what we came through.“To go - up takes a lot of courage and even in the last game against Albania people were saying it should be a walkover.“But Wales were beaten by Albania on Tuesday and they played a strong team with Gareth Bale playing.“I think that needs to be recognised as well because we took the form from that game into the Israel game which is nice.”For Fraser, two victories to finish off the calendar year is the perfect send-off for this Scotland side as they await their fate for the European Championship qualying proper.The victory over Israel saw the Scots win their Nations League group and gain promotion to League B – but also gave them a back-up chance through a play-off, should they fail in the traditional method of qualying.The Aberdonian, however, says the unity in the squad can see them avoid even needing the play-off.“For these two games the togetherness has been massive,” he added.“I’ve been doing stuff with Graeme Shinnie going for food and things on days off.“When you know each other’s backgrounds it makes you want to fight even more for them.“It’s hard when you only see them in international squads which can be only four or five games a season.“But you want to fight for them and when you do things together on days off and know their backgrounds you want to fight for them even more.“Shinnie and I have known each other for a long time and it’s always good to catch up.“It was good to see Graeme make his first competitive appearance against Israel and it’s great to see him doing well.”Former Dundee United man Stuart Armstrong echoed the belief the squad has in each other.He said: “It’s been a great pleasure to join up with the squad over the last three months and to get something out of it, some progress is a great feeling.“It’s not often Scotland top a group and that’s something we’re really pleased about. We’ve been good in recent years and been nearly there, just missing out here and there but on Tuesday we won, we top the group and can be happy.“I think we’re very together as a team and there is a lot of belief, a lot of unity and a lot of confidence and the win on Tuesday only enhances that.”

story: Dundee striker Benjamin Kallman is a major doubt for next week’s trip to Hibs as he battles a knee complaint.The Finnish international, who has been on standby for his national side over this international break, picked up the problem in the draw with St Mirren at Dens last week.Manager Jim McIntyre confirmed the on-loan frontman had fluid on his knee and the club are monitoring his progress ahead of the trip to Easter Road.The -year-old has since posted on social media a photo of his knee wrapped up in an attempt to reduce the problem, complete with an unhappy face emoji.Kallman has been a regular pick for the new Dens gaffer since taking over a month ago, missing only the Motherwell match due to concussion.And his absence will be a blow to the Dark Blues, should the treatment not work in time, with a severe lack of goals leaving the side bottom of the Premiership table and likely replacement Sofien Moussa still to grab a league strike this campaign.

title: dundee united given go ahead to create sports bar opposite tannadice
story: Plans for a Dundee United sports bar opposite Tannadice have been approved by the city council.The club put forward proposals earlier this year to transform the storage facility across the road from the stadium into a hospitality venue, sports bar andsuite for fans.Arabs will be able to make use of the venue as part of a hospitality package during United games.Lunches and dinners will be offered to supporters who will then walk over to the stadium for the game.There will be an informal seating and dance floor as well as a beer garden.The new venue will open flexibly but it will not be used as a bar outwith football games or private events.The club hopes the venue will be open until am although restrictions have been put in place by the council, including closing the beer garden at pm from September-June and pm during the summer months of July and August.The decision notice states: “The development hereby approved shall only be used for hospitality, s and sporting events associated with Dundee United Football Club and the premises shall not be used as a public house at any other time.”Mike Barile, secretary of the Arab Trust, welcomed the news that the application for the bar has been approved.He said: “It’s excellent that fans can go there to have a drink.“It will help contribute towards the club at the same time.“They can meet like-minded supporters and it’s in an ideal location for fans to meet friends before and after games.“I think that it’s good for all football fans to meet and exchange banter.“And it’s good for the football club. title: mcintyre believes jesse curran can be a real star for dundee
story: Dundee boss Jim McIntyre wants wide player Jesse Curran to believe in himself to develop his “real potential”.The -year-old has been an ever-present since Jim took the managerial reins at Dens Park and has impressed all season in what is his rookie campaign as a regular first-team player.The young Australian has even drawn admiring glances from former England coach Sven-Goran Eriksson in his new role as manager of the Philippines.Curran has links to the South-East Asian country through his parents but is more than likely to hold off in the hope his country of birth Australia come calling.He’s even been considered for a Scotland U  call-up.All that is irrelevant to the Dens gaffer, however, he needs Curran playing well for Dundee first and foremost.Jim said: “Jesse has been good for me since I’ve come in.“He’s a player I think has real potential but, like any young player, he needs to believe in himself a wee bit more. I’ve been very pleased with what we’ve seen from him so far.”Curran’s role has changed under the new manager after previous boss Neil McCann wanted to develop him into an attacking full-back.McIntyre, though, sees him further up the pitch where he can use his pace to hurt opposing teams more directly.Also able to play as a central midfielder, Curran’s versatility has its uses for a manager but Jim has urged the young Aussie to “nail down a position” to really fulfil the potential he sees in him.The Dens boss said: “I see him playing further forward rather than right-back, though I know he can play there. He has that athleticism you need to play full-back, wing-back as well but I think you can get goals out of him.“He’s versatile but I think sometimes with players you need to nail down a position so we’re trying to do that with Jesse.“But I definitely see him in the midfield area.”Curran is expected to continue in that right-wing role for the Dark Blues at Hibs on Saturday despite having fit-again Roarie Deacon as competition.The former Sutton United man missed the draw with St Mirren with a thigh strain but trained this week and is available.Sven-Goran Eriksson wants Dundee youngster Jesse Curran" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp sven-goran-eriksson-wants-dundee-youngster-jesse-curran embed # secretxcPQdfeTm" data-secret"xcPQdfeTm" width"" "" title"#Sven-Goran Eriksson wants Dundee youngster Jesse Curran# # Evening " frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"

title: no parking bus at hibees for dundee
story: Jim McIntyre has no plans to park the bus this coming weekend as his Dundee side travel to free-scoring Hibs in the Premiership.The Dark Blues have the leakiest defence in the ision while the Hibees have notched  in five league matches at Easter Road ahead of their clash on Saturday.The Dens gaffer is under no illusions how tough it will be against Neil Lennon’s side, though he’s seen encouragement from his side over the past couple of matches.And he’s planning to put their opponents “under pressure” as his side aim for a much-needed result.He said: “Things were taken on from the Motherwell game and things were more positive with the St Mirren performance and it’s about trying to turn small margins into points.“We know we are facing a top side in Hibs who have done a fantastic job this season, are an exciting team to watch and have a lot of attacking threat but we have to go there and put them under pressure.”Of late, however, the Hibees haven’t won in their last four – but that recent form won’t change how Dundee prepare.“You are going to have peaks and troughs through any season but I’m sure them being at home Lenny will have them fired up,” added Jim.“We know they have good players and will be looking to take maximum points but from our own end the encouraging signs have been there and we want to try to build on the St Mirren result.“The boys clearly know how I work now after a month. title: revealed this is why helicopters and loud bangs were heard over local area
story: Residents were woken by “low-flying” helicopters and “loud bangs” as military aircraft carried out a series of exercises over Tayside.The manoeuvres, involving Apache and Wildcat helicopters, sparked a flurry of activity on social media from people living in the area around Carnoustie.It is understood that the loud bangs were movie-stye special effects used as part of a battle-field simulation exercise at the Barry Buddon training grounds.No live ammunition was used.Residents also said flares had been lit at Barry Buddon.One resident posted: “Helicopter just flew really low along Dalhousie Road, heading towards Dundee.“Thought it was about to land on our roof!”Scott Robertson said: “Sounded like explosions!”Some locals were angry they hadn’t been notied in advance.Kimmy Taylor wrote on Facebook: “Not that I’m concerned # but some warning for the community before now would’ve been a good idea “Some residents may have found this very unsettling.”Muriel Glen added: “Yes, people should be informed about these exercises beforehand.“Most people wouldn’t mind security manoeuvres taking placethey were forewarned.”The Ministry of Defence lists a -hour exercise called Talon Python, involving helicopters, as taking place across Scotland between November  and .The MoD said: “Due to two routine military exercises, there may be an increase in helicopter activity in the area between November -December  inclusive.“Both exercises will involve some night flying around the coastal area.“However, as the helicopters, in the main, are not based at Leuchars, it’s expected the activity will be low level.“Any low flying complaints should be forwarded to the MoD Low Flying Complaints and Enquiries Unit on SWK-lowflying@mod.gov.uk or   .”

title: scottish ice cream producer scoops dundee parlour which should be open by january
story: Scoops at the ready – famed Scottish ice cream producer Crolla’s is preparing to open a parlour in Dundee.The renowned firm, set up by Italian immigrant Serafino Crolla in Glasgow in , has secured new premises in Perth Road which it aims to open by January.The cafe, at  Perth Road, near the Sinderins area, will offer sweet treats such as sundaes, brownies and ice cream bowls as well as Crolla’s signature “coldstone creations” – a melding of ice cream, toppings and sauce created on a marble slab.Peter Crolla Jr, managing director of the firm, said the fit–out of the unit had already begun, despite the ink on the leasing agreement barely being dry.He told the Tele: “The lease was signed on November  and the fit–out has already started. We hope to be open early January with the potential to open late December. It’s been two years but we’re almost there.”Crolla’s had hoped to open their first Dundee parlour at another location on Perth Road early last year.However, its bid for the site fell through at the last minute, as did a further attempt to secure a lease at the retail units adjacent to Aldi on Arbroath Road later in the year.The proposals for the latter had been agreed – and then the German supermarket giant pulled out of the deal after deciding to sell the units.Peter added: “Our first franchise store was in Aberdeen and since then we have also opened in Edinburgh, Llandudno and High Wycombe.“Even with interested franchisees in Dundee from the start, we have not had much luck with being able to sign a lease on the units we have been interested in.”He said that Dundee had been on Crolla’s radar for some time after it began opening ice cream shops.The firm is also poised to start trading where in the UK, with branches lined up for Preston, Nottingham and Bury.“Dundee is quite an up-and- coming city and a place we wanted to have a store in,” said Peter.“We’re not looking at flooding the city with two or three of them – it will probably just be the one.“We really like the location on the Perth Road, as there seems to be a bit of a buzz around there.“There aren’t many things like this in Dundee either – up in Aberdeen, for example, the market for ice cream shops is becoming quite saturated.“For Dundee, it’s something a bit dferent.“We’re really looking forward to opening up.”

title: win against alloa could see dundee united eat into ayrs lead
story: Dundee United go into today’s re-arranged Championship clash with Alloa knowing they can eat into the gap at the top of the table.The weekend saw leaders Ayr United slip up when they were held at home by Morton.It means three points for the Tangerines today will mean a deficit that stood at eight when gaffer Robbie Neilson took over last month would be down to just three.And it would leave them able to wipe out the Honest Men’s advantage when the pair meet at Tannadice next week, though they could still trail Ross County, who currently lie second.Robbie has stressed he and his players will be looking no further forward than today’s outing but already the meeting with Ayr on Friday week is shaping up to be one of the most important games of the season so far.United remain hopeful of having skipper Fraser Fyvie, centre-half Frederic Frans and full-back Callum Booth available for today.They were all stepping up their work in training over the weekend after injury problems.If they’ve suffered no reactions, they’ll be in the squad.And in the case of Frans and Booth, both of whom have missed games, the manager has admitted that would give him a nice selection headache.“They have been doing well in the team but so have the players who’ve taken over from them while they were injured,” said Robbie.The reserves are not in action this week and don’t have another competitive fixture until they’re due to face Celtic in a league game early next month.
